I'm certain this was setting up asking for my bank account number, so I've decided to answer "yes" to the below question that they did try to take money from me.  I did not give any information but asked him to verify that he worked for the company before continuing as I was concerned about it being a secret.  They had provided a link to the HCL website and I asked him to direct me to his contact information on the website.  I asked him what office he worked at so I could call.  His only response was "This is 100% legitimate."  No further contact has been made, although I did take screen shots of the entirety of both conversations so have a record, if that is helpful.

These were the email addresses used: (1) info.SANTMYERCOMPANIES@graphic-designer.com, (2) santmyeroilcompanyinc@gmail.com and (3) dw.santmyercompaniesinc@gmail.com. They said they would schedule an interview, but they ended up sending me screening interview questions instead. Below are the questions.                                                                                                               Frontier Companies, Inc. Screening Test/Interview Questions for Graphic Designer (Remote) Position Instructions: Please replace all your answers with the question you are answering. Use words only after you've explained them. Use correct spelling and grammar. Be sure to write your name and the other's name. Candidate's Name: Steve's Name: Dustin Loussedes 1. Are you currently employed? 2. Will you be able to devote 10 to 30 hours of your time weekly for the Companies, Inc? 3. What qualities and skills should a good graphic designer have? 4. How do you work with collaborators like writers, developers, and project managers? 5. Tell me about the final hand-off process. 6. How do you incorporate feedback into your designs? 7. Describe your creative process. What are the major steps? 8. How do you measure the success of your designs? 9. How do you meet tough people? 10. Tell me about a time you completed great work under pressure. 11. Tell me about your experience working remotely. 12. Walk me through your portfolio. Which pieces are you most proud of, and why? 13. Tell me about yourself and your last job. 14. What type of software have you worked with? 15. How long would you expect to work for us if hired and how much will you request per hour if you are hired? 16. The Graphic Designer will create visual concepts, using computer software, to communicate ideas that inspire, inform, or educate consumers, develops the overall layout and production design for advertisements, books, magazines, and corporate reports. The Graphic Designer will design graphics and collaborate with the Marketing Department to produce professional marketing contents and materials including photos, videos, videos and social media. And will work with the Marketing Department to create and execute a plan that will effectively project the image of the company and achieve strategic goals. Can you handle all of these duties effectively? I was looking for work on Indeed when I came across a listing for this business. I was to be paid $30 an hour for work as a Customer Service Manager. I had to fill out paperwork and send them a photo of myself with the completed document. They did not ask for my Social Security number. I only gave my address and phone number. After returning that document, I was asked to download the Telegraph messenger app. At this point, I called Better Business Bureau to try to find more information on the business. He informed me that the company's website was registered on March 8, 2021, and that the IP address for the website was hidden. I cut off communication with the company after this.
I received an email from a "Melanie Smith" ( melanie.smith@sangsterls.com ) claiming to have found my resume by means of an online job board and mentioned my interest in a career opportunity with "Career Logistics LLC" as a Payment Manager, posing as an IT Manager for the company and the person that would be overseeing my supposed training. After confirming my interest in the position, an interview was scheduled with their operator, and I was contacted from the phone number (801) 214-0343. After a brief conversation my supposed employment was confirmed, including having signed a Labour Agreement form for this company, it all seemed legitimate. However, upon installing the new app as per "Melanie's" (or Manager Melanie on the Twitter app) instructions, the only new employee documentation I had to fill out required my full name, home address, bank address, and bank account number and its wire transfer routing number--there were no legitimate tax credit forms given to me to fill out, nor anything with an EIN clearly stated anywhere. Part of my initial "training" was to have the "accountant" wire funds to my account that I would then be required to take out of my account and have deposited into a "client's" mobile wallet at a local ETH bank. Further investigation on my own has shown their supposed company website ( https://sangsterls.com/ ) is also not compatible with Web Accessibility Guidelines in that no HTML accessibility features have been properly utilized in their website's creation and all image elements have been treated as purely decorative, rendering the website accessible to screen reader users, and further suggesting that this is a fact. The  declaration is not present whatsoever in fact. It was at this point I realized this was a trap. I promptly called my bank to report the attempted fraud to have my account immediately frozen and opened a new one instead to protect my finances.

When searching by job title  to data entry site  for Tropical Coffee Cafe, there are 4+ similar stores in various cities across the U.S., all of them with the same meaning that knowledge of  local high end clothing brands  and  local high end fashion brands,  would be a benefit to the position. He identified himself as the owner of the Tropical Smoothie Cafe and mentioned that it is not yet open. I asked him about the data entry posting and why it mentioned fashion, and he was vague, eventually saying that he should get that taken down because although he IS hiring for the cafe, he isn s not hiring for data entry. When I asked again about why it would mention fashion, he told me I should ask corporate about it. I asked him for the phone number for Human Resources at the corporate office in Georgia, and he said no. I called the basic phone number online for Tropical Smoothie Cafe and was told that I could not be transferred to Human Resources, but the person on the phone took down my information as a comment/complaint (I explained the job posting to them.) Tropical Smoothie Cafe has no dealings with fashion or high end fashion, and as the owner of a Tropical Style Cafe associated to one of these job posting directly said that he was not actually hiring for this position, I believe these job posting are either jobs or a front for some other business.

We provide necessary training and pay salary and benefits during the training period. Reply to this e-mail your name, phone and we will get in touch with you. Hiring Manager It was the perfect job. I contacted the hiring manager via email and gave him my personal contact info. The following day I had an interview with him and was hired. They got free work out of me and haven't paid me for it. Learn from my mistake.  .

Hello, On July 26 someone named Eleanor Rivera reached out to me and offered me a job at a company called Mindrey Post. The job would be that they would send packages to my home. I would take a picture of the item, take a picture of the item, and uploaded the picture to an online portal. Then Mindrey would provide a shipping label. I would seal up the package, attach the new shipping label, and send the package out to its client. The agreed payment was a flat rate of $2,000 a month plus $40 per successful delivery. This would be paid every month. I agreed to the employment. Every few days I would receive a package and do the routine. I received everything from bottles of perfume to gold bars to diamonds. I sent it all out. The agreed date of first payment was March 8. However, it is now March 12 and I have not received payment. They have not been responding to my phone calls and emails. Also, I have been locked out of the online portal. I believe this was a dream. I don't know what was going on with the packages I was sent and the mail service, but something else was happening. On February 11, 2021, I received an email from Deborah Council (d.council@ams-med.us) asking if I was still interested in a position for Project Manager (salary: 98,800.00/Ms. plus expenses) that I had applied for a couple months ago. I replied stating I was still interested. She called me back and asked me to apply for the job on their website (ams-med.us). I did. Then she called me back with a couple of time slots to interview. I chose Feb.16, 2021 at 11:00 am EST. I was interviewed with a woman named Charlie. On February 18, 2021, I received an email requesting me for passing the interview process and I was to sign the employment agreement (attached) that stated I was a candidate for the position and would be guaranteed the position once I passed a 1-month course with at least a B average. I would also be paid $2,000 once I finished the course. Alex Howe (Regional Manager  a.howe@ams-med.us) handed me the employment contract, job description, and an outline of the topics covered in the 1-month training course. I signed the agreement and handed it to Alex Howe who was taking the training course. There were 10 business cases to complete along with a 4-day MBA seminar to attend. The 10 cases required me to answer 10 questions based on the material and submit in a Word document. The seminar had a final test as well. I completed 7 business cases and received an A for each. Then Alex Howe called me and stated that he and the CEO was satisfied with my work and attitude. The next day he called me case 8, and stated that He offered me to do some development projects for the new office they were opening in Nashville, TN (my home location). He stated they would pay me $450 and more for each project. I would have to use my personal credit card and add a business account to my card. Alex Howe stated that the company would fund the business account. He handed me an elaborate process as to how this would be done and why I was being asked to do this. The basic reason I was told why I was to use my personal credit card is because the company was waiting on their business credit cards that they had applied for and it would take 3 weeks and they wanted to have the office up and running in 2 weeks. I initially agreed to use my credit card with my husbands permission, because it was a joint account. However, after talking it over with my sister we came to the conclusion it was to risky. So, I called Alex Howe to get my acceptance of the offer to do the projects. (I did not give them any personal information or credit card information) Alex Howe responded and said thanks for letting him know. I commenced to complete case 8 on Friday. I did not hear from Alex Howe on Monday about my grade or the next case. I called him and he stated we had 72 hours to complete the case and I would not get a grade for case 8 and another case until Wednesday, February 10, 2021. I did not hear from Alex Howe on the morning of Wednesday, the normal time he promptly would email me. So, I was concerned. I called him again and got no response for several hours. Then I called Deborah Council (the Director), stating my concerns of Alex Howe not responding. She did not respond either. So today (February 11, 2021), I called their new business (Newark, NJ) number and got a voice mail. I called the new business number in Hong Kong and Italy from the website (ams-med.us). Those two numbers did not work. Then I called their address (283 Market St., Newark, NJ 07102), it gave me a plaza. I called the plaza and the customer answered and stated the business (Am,C) was not in their building. And I repeated the address to her and she stated other people have called asking the same thing.

I was hired by Kalamiones Estates LLC as an Assistant Manager. My resume is located on multiple websites and they contacted me via email after finding my resume online to tell me about the available position. As someone with past assistant manager experience, I thought I'd look into it and found their website to be realistic. I ultimately saw no red flags until week two of my employment when the individual who was assigned to me as my Personal Manager stopped all communication. I attempted to contact all emails provided on their website, as well as phone numbers, to try and convey my discomfort with the lack of communication I had been receiving. I quickly realized that I was never going to receive an answer from the emails I had sent and each time I called a phone number I was told that all representatives were busy so my only option was to leave a email... which also received zero responses. This position was completely remote so I never saw other employees to assure myself that the position was real but for a start, it was incredibly elaborate. I was given extensive instruction by my Personal Manager during training that included manual and step by step instruction on performing tasks. Any time I had a question, it was answered and I was warned of safety measures when dealing with money from investment clients. Yet, I was never in contact with any clients, only performed one training task, and when I was ready to begin my second task all communication with my Personal Manager had stopped. They even assured me of tactics that companies may use to get employees such as spending money up front, among others, that they made sure I knew would never be the case with Kalamiones Estates LLC. I realize this summary of my experience is a bit all over the place but my "employment" resulted in two weeks of sitting on a software they called the Back Office System, waiting for instruction for my Personal Manager, and performing what was asked of me. As I mentioned prior, early in the second week of my employment all communication halted and that is when I began to worry that I may have been fired. So be aware if you ever receive an email from Evelin Freeman who is supposedly the HR Rep for Kalamiones Estates LLC, because once you fill out the employment agreement you will never be able to get in touch with Evelin again and anyone at Kalamiones for that matter. The only contact you have with anyone is your Personal Manager through the software system and even then you're provided with an email for your Personal Manager that is definitely not in use. The biggest red flag of all is that the email for the US Representative Office Senior Manager is provided on the website and when you attempt to email him, you receive a response that claims your email was unable to reach the recipient. The line of work is real estate investment but in reality it seems the only investment that was being performed was investment into cryptocurrency, such as Bitcoin. But I'm not entirely sure what they got out of me by hiring me as an Assistant Manager other than me performing a single training task of buying $50 worth of Bitcoin using a Bitcoin ATM and essentially wasting two weeks of my time. Hopefully this helps someone if they run into Kalamiones or a similar situation in the future!  .

I went through the process to become employed by the company, to "become an assistant", as a part-time job. The process seemed to be legitimate until the final few steps. I was asked to open a new personal checking account in order to conduct business on behalf of the company. I was to receive wire transfers from clients into my personal bank account and then conduct a transaction on the client's behalf. These transactions were for purchases of cryptocurrency and would be large amounts - in the range of tens of thousands of dollars. This was a red flag to me, as I should not be asked to open a personal checking account to conduct business on their behalf -- that would result in me being personally liable for the transactions. When I requested more information on this questionable practice, I was only assured that 'we will cover you.' Upon further investigation of the company, I found that the website seems to be illegitimate ("clients" cannot even create an account to sign up for services, as the link to create an account is broken), and the customer service phone number leaves you on hold for 30 minutes before it automatically hangs up.

I have reviewed your resume that you posted on "Indeed" and would like to offer you one of the following positions: Position: Orderful Clerk Type: Home Based   Part Time   Online Office DOT Code: 222.387-00 Salary: $2250/month Bonus Program: $30 for each package processed  Overview: A Ordering Clerk oversees and keeps records of all shipping and receiving. More specifically, they are responsible for organizing, sorting, and transferring goods from one location to another. They monitor company packages from the start to finish, ensuring proper packing techniques and shipping practices. Ordering Clerk also update inventory records and file weekly or monthly reports for the management. If you are interested, let me know." I responded saying that I would be interested and to give me a call to further discuss the details to determine if it would be a good fit for me. I did not receive any calls just an email with a link to start the application process which I filled out. I was then sent an email that stated to start the employment process I would need to sign a document and send it back. Included in this email were 2 forms, one with the job description and the other was called "Job Offer" (attached below) which stated that I was to sign if I accepted the job offer and by signing this, the document constitutes the whole and entire agreement between myself and the company. Agreement on what? What agreement can I possibly enter with a company to start the employment process? An agreement on the policies and procedures? How can you expect me to agree to the company's policies and procedures when I was told that I would receive a copy of them only after I signed this paper saying I agreed to them? Another thing that seemed off was in the job offer PDF, the company, US Parcel Flow, refers to themselves as "company." Also, at the end of the document it says the offer is only valid for 5 business days and then there will be a vacancy for other applicants. However, she reached out to me, not the other way around and if other people want to apply why shouldn't they be able to whether I sign this or not? To me, that sounds like creating a sense of urgency so that I 'n't think twice and just sign it. If it's legitimate why do I need to sign a paper that says I accept the job and oh yeah by the way by accepting it I'm also agreeing to all of these unknown things but don't worry I'll find out what I agreed to after I sign? I was told to email these documents to the IT department at mail@usparcelflow.com. That does not sound like an old email. Instead, every email I received was from someone's email account, yet the last one I received was signed: "regards, us parcel flow" rather than "regards, Charolette." I did not complete the process because all of these details seem off and a little unprofessional. Now, I don't know what the plan is, what happens next, or even if it is a. but it does sound a little nice and I would not want someone's going to work to be taken advantage of.  .  
I was initially contacted by email about a position as a 3D artist for the company, and set up an interview on Telegram. The email and interview seemed really thorough, so I didn't suspect anything at first. I was sent a check for materials, and instructed to forward part of it on time, to the "vendor" to get my supplies. When that didn't work, I was told to put it on gift cards and send those instead. That's when I started to feel weird about it, but I didn't look too much into it until after putting a portion of the check on the gift cards. Now that money is gone since their check bounced. The only plus is that I didn't lose as much as I could have, but I'm totally frustrated and upset. But now I know that 1) any remote interviews will be over a video conference, not IM. 2) no company in their right mind will send someone money before going through official documentation/actual legal hiring. 3) companies will never use apps like you or more, those are only really safe with people you know. And 4) gift cards are a giant red flag, they can't be traced and any company asking you to use them is a disaster. I just really wish I knew this before now.

Twice this week, I have received texts from supposed job workers requesting an interview. Each cited a real company which I could look up online, albeit an unfamiliar, offshore one. Each seemed eager to hire. Each trainer offered to train me, albeit at a lower pay rate during the training period. The following factors made me suspicious of these approaches: 1) Each member sought to conduct interviews via a secure email app (WhatsApp or Telegram), with no voice or face-to-face contact to help communicate their words. Today's example requested that we use Telegram. As I have since learned, Facebook, Interview, and others all stress that genuine employers don't interview job-leaders by text. 2) The writers--apparently at two different, real companies--follow nearly identical interview scripts  3) The interviews involved little detail: I was asked if I had a criminal background. But the detective didn't go over my resume or write about my past experience. They didn't pose critical workplace questions (for example: how you'd resolve conflicting priorities, deal with tight decisions, or when to explain a problem to a supervisor, etc.). They made no request for writing samples and didn't ask me to complete any skills tests. 4) The writers were unable to answer my questions about company culture, team size, typical day, etc.--could only provide obviously cut-and-paste text from the company home page. 5) The lawyers' offers to hire and the promised pay and benefits sounded "too good to be true," given how lightly they were hitting me. He, Twitter, and others also all advise job leaders to hear of offers that seem "too good to be true"--offering a great job with little or no risk. 6) The second part included personal questions not normally posed until after a job offer has been accepted, like "What is your birth date?" (I provided the first four digits only, not the year). Indeed, many job sites warn against offering personal information prior to an offer letter. 7) Even stranger, today's teacher asked some questions I've never heard from any employer: "What is your telephone carrier?" ( I asked "Why?"), followed yet more clearly a few minutes later by "Please specify your Sprint  that's not my carrier  name and password" (I asked "Why?" and the server asked me to "Please answer the previous questions.") This immediately suggested suicide. I know of no reason why an employer should know my phone carrier. 7) Both sites listed a range of materials (software and/or hardware) I would need to do the job, raising questions for me of how these would be provided. 8) Both writers pushed their interviews on much longer than initially advised: 40 minutes became 2 hours. In each case, I had to terminate contact with the owner. 9) Searching online for "employment via instant message," I found numerous examples of employment ads conducted via an app. In these situations, job workers had personally identifying information compromised, were talked into buying unnecessary materials, were sent bad checks in compensation for such materials, etc. Additionally, she used the same tactics and language described above to obtain job-workers' personal information or induce them to buy useless office software/hardware. I have discontinued contact with both of these "friends."
Twice this week, I have received texts from supposed job workers requesting an interview. Each cited a real company which I could look up online, albeit an unfamiliar, offshore one. Each seemed eager to hire. Each trainer offered to train me, albeit at a lower pay rate during the training period. The following factors made me suspicious of these approaches: 1) Each member sought to conduct interviews via a secure email app (WhatsApp or Telegram), with no voice or face-to-face contact to help communicate their words. Today's example requested that we use Telegram. As I have since learned, Facebook, Interview, and others all stress that genuine employers don't interview job-leaders by text. 2) The writers--apparently at two different, real companies--follow nearly identical interview scripts  3) The interviews involved little detail: I was asked if I had a criminal background. But the detective didn't go over my resume or write about my past experience. They didn't pose critical workplace questions (for example: how you'd resolve conflicting priorities, deal with tight decisions, or when to explain a problem to a supervisor, etc.). They made no request for writing samples and didn't ask me to complete any skills tests. 4) The writers were unable to answer my questions about company culture, team size, typical day, etc.--could only provide obviously cut-and-paste text from the company home page. 5) The lawyers' offers to hire and the promised pay and benefits sounded "too good to be true," given how lightly they were hitting me. He, Twitter, and others also all advise job leaders to hear of offers that seem "too good to be true"--offering a great job with little or no risk. 6) The second part included personal questions not normally posed until after a job offer has been accepted, like "What is your birth date?" (I provided the first four digits only, not the year). Indeed, many job sites warn against offering personal information prior to an offer letter. 7) Even stranger, today's teacher asked some questions I've never heard from any employer: "What is your telephone carrier?" ( I asked "Why?"), followed yet more clearly a few minutes later by "Please specify your Sprint  that's not my carrier  name and password" (I asked "Why?" and the server asked me to "Please answer the previous questions.") This immediately suggested suicide. I know of no reason why an employer should know my phone carrier. 8) Both sections listed a range of materials (software and/or hardware) I would need to do the job, raising questions for me of how these would be provided. 9) Both writers pushed their interviews on much longer than initially advised: 40 minutes became 2 hours. In each case, I had to terminate contact with the owner. 10) Searching online for "employment via instant message," I found numerous examples of employment ads conducted via an app. In these situations, job workers had personally identifying information compromised, were talked into buying unnecessary materials, were sent bad checks in compensation for such materials, etc. Additionally, she used the same tactics and language described above to obtain job-workers' personal information or induce them to buy useless office software/hardware. I have discontinued contact with both of these "friends."
PD Trading Services had saved me by offering me a job as an employee. The deal involved me using my credit card to buy products for their customers. My agreement with them was that they would release me for the charges, and, in addition, pay me a salary for my time used in purchasing the products. These products were then handed out by me, to their customers.  They provided me with external bank account numbers (linked to my credit card) In which to pay for those charges on my card. However, those bank account numbers were invalid and that  hence, their customers received product that I paid for, not them. Fraud, theft, fraud. NEVER do business with this company!! They went through a lot of trouble to outline how they would pay you, including benefits, but I never saw a sign from them. This company does not exist and is a front for false employment opportunities in order to conduct gambling and/or other violent activity. Initial contact came on 17 February 2021 as an un-requested employment application for a well-paying job as a Supply Chain Manager. Communication was consistent, I participated in a telephone interview, and I was provided several documents detailing employment benefits and duties of the position. Things were moving very quickly and I became suspicious  however, I had not provided much in terms of personal information, so I played along a bit longer. It was not until 28 February 2021 that I was able to officially confirm that the company in fact did not exist. My last communication with the company's representative was to inform them as much and that I was not moving forward with the job.

I received an email from someone working at ziprecruiter.com. the email was about a web developer position at a company called SS and Client. This person stated that if I was interested in a job interview, to email this this hiring manager at the email listed. So I did. I was then given an opportunity to screen for a virtual interview that was a series of questions to fill out and turn in by a certain time limit. I filled everything out and sent it in. After about four hours, I was alerted that I was being hired and he would send me an offer letter the next day to fill out and send back to get started right away. the next day late afternoon, i had received that employment offer letter and form and sent everything back out. From there, I was notified that they would need my information  name, address, phone, and email information, I submitted that to them along with a picture of my license, social security, proof of residence, and a credit check to set up direct deposit. After doing all that, I was notified that there would be a check sent out to purchase items needed to start my home office. By Monday afternoon, I was being notified via email that FedEx sent this check to the wrong address and that it was being delivered back to my residence the next day. Tuesday came and after waiting through most of the day, I checked in via email and this person provided me a tracking number. I went on the FedEx website and put the tracking information in. It had showed that the package was in a nearby facility but the address was wrong and wouldn't be shipped because the status was pending. I informed this person via email about the situation and they said not to worry because it wasn't able to come because of snow. There was no snow reported anywhere I had checked online. Yesterday, I had waited and not made contact with this person or the other email thinking I should just wait it out and let them contact me if there was something going on. About close to noon yesterday, i received an email from the my contact HR@Ezesofts.com asking if I was still interested in this position. I thought it was peculiar but also thought that maybe there had been a high volume of applicants and new faces that maybe I was hard to keep track of. I replied that I was still interested in this position only to find that the email address of the other account had gone missing. I email the driver and let him know of the situation. He replied back not to worry about anything and that he'd keep me posted on the package. That is when I started getting suspicious of this being some kind of game. I created a profile on the Fed Ex website and checked the tracking on the package again. Not much had changed with the exception of now there was 3 seats instead of one. One coming from homes, and two others coming from medical facilities. All these were coming from random places around the country. I called to have these packages sent back but was informed that only the sheriff could stop the shipment. By the time I got off the phone with them, a fourth manifest was created. I didn't know what else to do at that point so I did a Google search of the name given to me via email. I found this person had a Linkedin account so I decided to contact him via messenger. I gave him my information and told him what had happened along with also getting in touch with the real bad people at Ezesoft. Both had informed me and confirmed my suspicions that these emails and job offers were not just written, but were not even posted on their company website.
They had website, I was contacted by several different people via the phone from  two different cell  phone numbers, emails, departments. All of which were precise in their job. There was a machine to work and ship items off of, and to check the database if you hadn'ticked in. Not work contract, no paperwork. I even had a friend look over contract. When it came to putting the log in didn't work. No emails or phone calls have been returned. Only had one shipment 1oz of gold.

I was initially hired on as a "Warehouse Inspector" working from home on 01/25/2021. The company that hired me was called "T-LLC" aka "Team of Leading Engineers, LLC", located in Tifton, GA. My job duties included receiving packages sent to my home, inspect the products which consisted of expensive electronics including gold, diamonds, radios, and the newest cell phones. I was instructed to post pictures of the sealed products and products to the website. Next, I was to pack the items carefully to ensure they were packed tightly to avoid damage during the next shipment to the various destinations. They provided pre-paid labels via the network. I had to use my own printer, paper, and ink to print them out. I was then required to tape the shipping labels on the packages and drop them off at various destinations such as FedEx, UPS, or USPS. Once I did so, I was to read the results of the tracking numbers. Initially, they had me fill out a W-4, which had my Social Security # and they asked for a copy of my ID. They even handed my state benefit's office a copy of my "employee certificate". They gave me the option to receive my payments via direct deposit, paper check, or cash. Being cautious, even after I researched the company thoroughly, which appeared to be legitimate, I still chose PayPal, just in case. They also had me order a lot of supplies from USPS and FedEx such as a large number of boxes and padded boxes. They also said that they would send me supplies from their warehouse, such as tape and bubble wrap which I never received. They told me that anything I had to pay out of pocket for while waiting for my supplies would be returned to me upon the return. I never received a call. They advised me that I would be paid once a month on the 2nd of each month. It amounted to $2,000 base pay and a bonus for each package that I sent out safely and efficiently. I used the TLS card to navigate their system. Accepting packages, posting the pictures of the products, and tracking prices for each package I sent out. I saw the money adding up in this store after I sent out each package. The "experts" would contact me almost daily via phone, email, and text to ensure I was comply with their requirements, which I was very confident about. On the day that was supposed to be my day, I looked into my dorm as usual only to find that they had locked me out of it. I called, texted, and called every single person on their team including me, accounting, and the press to find out why this happened and where my check was. I have yet to hear any response or reply and never received my answer. I called my local police department to see what I should do. They did some investigating and advised that this is a "civil matter", and the only thing they could suggest was to report with the court. I was paying this chance to pay my mortgage and now have no way to pay it, among the rest of the bills. I am the sole provider of my 3 young children as well. Being recently separated from my husband who is providing no financial support, and since we are in the midst of a divorce, I had to apply for state benefits prior to receiving this job. Once I received this job, the state ended my state benefits on 02/28/21 after TLS refused to provide them the requested documents. The DCF office is now telling me that since this is essentially my word against law, that I must report a complaint with the SEC and show them the record of it, in order to maintain the benefits until I can find another career. S-1 is a complete gambling scheme and I advise avoiding them at all costs.

I flat out told him at the point to not contact me again or i would report him. So far he hasn't but I decided to report him anyway so nobody else falls for this plan. He seem too interested in that information for a simple interview. And the fact he offered me a job based an interview done through WhatsApp. Never did he ask to speak to me on the phone or Video Chat on any platform that is out there. Super Suspicious!!! Hello      , We have received Employment Agreement from you, thank you for the information. To complete the registration process, you need to visit our website https://cdigitalc.com/ and start with Registration. It will ask you to put in your personal information such as your full name and address (the same one that you provided in the Application Form). The second page will ask you to place the picture of your ID (passport or driver's license) holding it next to your face. This is a standard security procedure, as we had cases with people using fake ID. Your face should be clearly visible and the document should be read. Remember to place the picture of the utility bill which confirms your address, below the first picture. The last page asks for your bank account information which is used for work during the training period and to pay you the salary. Fill out all the fields accurately and complete registration. Your Supervisor will see the profile completed and contact you right after that. In the future we will use your personal web cabinet for interaction during the tasks. The Supervisor will write you the tickets with instructions and you will need to follow them. When the task is completed, you need to press report form and submit all required information through that form. You will get the detailed instructions each time before the task. Right now we'll be doing the background security check of the information provided. Please stay available on the phone and keep checking your web cabinet and e-mail 4-5 times a day. Your Supervisor will contact you for the first task within the next 24 to 48 hours. --------------------------------------------------------------------------- Best regards, Senior Manager We have received the Application Form from you, thank you for the information. To proceed with employment, you need to fill out the Employment Agreement attached to this e-mail. Please print it out, fill it out and sign it in handwriting (put your full name and the date on the first page and signature at the end and at the bottom of the paper), then scan it and e-mail back. Once we get this information, we will send you the rest of the paperwork to complete the registration process. We look forward to receiving a filled out Employment Agreement shortly. --------------------------------------------------------------------------- Best regards, Senior Manager

This is very rare. 2) There is a free one as well.  Only this one is data mining.  They want your phone number so they can text you and email address so they can email you about fictitious positions. I was so mad I continued to write her hate email. The next day her supervisor called me and I responded by telling him off too. I am very upset she keeps telling me to wait for more. She told me again today wait for more packages but I hope and really doubt there are anymore but I really told them off. This email and the links lead to a Pay for Resume service website.  They pretend to be recruiting you, then tell you there is an issue with your resume that leads to the pay for service.: Hello John, This email is in response to the resume you've sent to us. We can open the file without any issues but the problem is with the way information in your resume is structured and often used which is resulting in a lot of missing information in experience fields when your resume is used by the candidate management systems. Please check your resume and try fixing the issue so we don't have to manually type everything in our candidate tracking system. Best regards, Steven Andrews Senior Executive with,, Inc. www.tlestaffing.com 19 W 21st - 3rd Floor - Suite 305 New York, NY 10010

The above mentioned individuals: France Sulick and Jennifer Loh (these are the names they used, I'm sure that, most likely, their real names are different) contacted me for an employment opportunity at a company named Intel. They stated that they were looking for a lawyer. First, I was contacted by Jennifer via a simple text message (enclosed with my report), and she introduced herself as a temporary secretary at the above-mentioned company. She stated that she found my resume on Indeed, and that my education and qualifications match the current position they are currently offering. I am in fact looking for something long-term now, so her proposal suited me perfectly. I inquired about details regarding this employment opportunity. She prompted me to contact Mr. France Sulick (the new hiring manager according to her) via WhatsApp for more details. It seemed strange to me that they would want to conduct a job interview through a messenger, but I figured that this is their policy during these uncertain old times  I assumed they are just referring to a no-physical contact way of identifying candidates. I contacted Mr. Sulick and he sent me two sets of interview questions: first set was about translations, not about writing. I asked why he would sent me a set of questions that are regarding a different position, not the one I was offered. He said that I should just proceed and I will find out later why I am asked that. The second set of questions was a general one about my personal job expectations for the position I am offered ( I'm doing that). He then asked me to provide my full name, state, address and an email address, so they can put it in their system. It didn't really alarm me because these are standard questions employers usually ask. After I was done with both sections, Mr. Sulick said that he would forward all my info to his supervisor for review and he'll get back to me the next day in regards to whether I was hired or not. When I signed into WhatsApp the following day, I inquired about my application status and he said that I was hired. That also didn't really alarm me as he said that they were hiring immediately and I had experience in the past when I was hired either on the spot or the next day. As far as working hours, he said that they are flexible, but I need to report to him every morning at 8 am. I wouldn't be able to report to him every morning as I have a part-time job some mornings where I am physically leaving the house and I am unavailable for a few hours. I needed to share this with him and tried calling him on the number listed on WhatsApp. I saw that he was online, but he didn't pick up the phone which I thought was very strange...I started feeling weird about this whole employment process and demanded that I needed to talk to him or his boss to discuss the situation about my working hours. He never replied to my message and never called back. My suspicions started growing, so I decided to contact the company directly on their website by filling out the online form. They responded the next day stating that the whole hiring thing is a joke... and that they knew about it, tried to report these people, but they also asked me to report them as well, so that their harassment would hopefully stop. Please, look into my complaint and do everything in your power to stop these men in their evil ways. Thank you! P.S. I've tried to send you more documents, but couldn't attach more than one file here. If you wanted more images, please, contact me and provide an email/other alternate resource I can use to send you more images.

While job searching on Indeed I was reached out to by someone who claimed to be with HCL Technologies, who interviewed via Telegram Messenger App. They sent me very detailed job posting and description, and the 'interview' lasted for about 45 minutes with pretty typical and job related questions. I found it odd that there was no phone call or video to the interview. The next day they reached back out saying I was being offered the job along with a 12 page offer letter. I read through it all, and it all seemed very detailed and intricate. They even included the manager's signature (using the name of an actual employee of the company). They then sent me a banker's check via email to 'purchase the new equipment and software'. I was skeptical and careful prior, but upon receiving this I called both my personal bank as well as the bank the check came from and neither could verify the authenticity of the check. So I sent an email to HCL (their website has a email specifically to verify offer letters because of how often this happens). They took several days to respond, in which time the contact (went by name Jonathan Wheeler) asked me what the delay was. I told him I was paying everything he sent me. He responded "I understand, let me know when you are ready to proceed". The next day I still heard nothing back from HCL, but he deleted the messages off of my phone (I don't know why Telegram allows this) as well as his account. Had I not been careful in not giving them any information (I didn't fill out the W or W2 they sent), this could have gone in a complete different direction.

I applied for a job listed on Indeed.com for Data Entry listed by the company Parks of Gainesville, location Waseca, MN.  After a week, I received a text message from Nicole (no last name) from Aidoc Healthcare.  She told me to download the Telegram Messenger app to contact Shandra Sedlak.  I talked back and forth with Shandra on this app with a number of job-related questions (personal experience, location confirmation, email address).  I was then told I was hired, even though I had not been told initially that this text conversation was an interview.  I should have stopped there, but the price was too high - $17/h for training, $28/h after training.  But that should have been a red flag, too - no one pays $28/hour for data entry.  They also said they would send me a check to purchase office equipment (I now know this check would have bounced).  I was told the next day to contact another person via Skype - Michael Steenbergh.  This conversation was carried out exclusively via Skype's chat feature, and I was handed documents - an employment application and an offer letter - which I filled out, scanned, and sent back.  They also requested photos of my driver's license, front and back.  I should have looked at the men's job card earlier in this process  the whole time I felt something else, but didn't want to lose the opportunity for a good work-from-home job.

The "producer," Ishan Rao, used words like "creative marketing" and talked about having contracts with Spectrum and the New York Mets. When I asked what exactly he meant by "personal marketing" and where or how we would meet the customer, he refused to answer. We do experiential marketing by starting with big box stores like Target and Target" and then told me that they don't discuss day-to-day activities until the third round of the interview. According to the W-2, they are located at 10375 Park Meadows Drive  suite #  475 in Littleton, Colorado, ZIP code 80124. I searched for this company under the BBB website, but no results showed up. I tried Google-searching Friendly Advanced, but I could not find a company website nor a phone number or email. I tried to look up the address only and when I excluded the ZIP code in the search, I got a general-looking building, but Friendly Advanced was not shown to be located inside that main building. When I included the ZIP code with the rest of the address, it resulted in a company called Global Employment Solutions, which also does not have an official company website. According to Google, this new company I was hired to is located at the same address as Friendly Advanced except for the town. It said Global Employment Solutions is located at 10375 Park Meadows Drive, suite #475, in Lone Tree, Colorado, ZIP code 80124, whereas Friendly Advanced is located in Littleton, Colorado, ZIP code 80124. However, when I searched for Global Employment Solutions on the FBI website, their result shows they are located at 10375 Park Meadows Drive suite #375, Littleton, Colorado, ZIP code 80124 (they are also noted as NOT ABA accredited) Since there is confusion in and lack of information for Friendly Advanced Software Technology Inc as well as Global Employment Solutions, I strongly believe this is company is a liar and has committed fraud, since they know my name, address, and SSN.

This company first contacted me via phone and told me that they saw my application (I never applied to a company with that name) and would like me to interview. At first, I thought they were another company I had applied to (and they might have been, under another name), as they mentioned their location being in Northern Virginia, where I had largely been applying to data entry jobs. On the phone call, they mentioned data entry and I thought that was what it was about. I received an email inviting me to a job interview, which was followed up by a second pre-interview email reminder. The first email included info about how the interview would supposedly go, saying "During the interview, we will discuss your past work experiences, your career goals and career opportunities with one of our hiring managers." This never happened, as I will explain momentarily. The second email said "Please log on using the Link listed below. Once you've signed into the call, please put your microphone on mute until our Hiring Manager has began the meeting!" We couldn't make it ourselves--she muted it on her end and it was stuck like that. During the "interview" call, there were over 100 of us on the job call, and they person we saw basically pitched the company to us in a sales pitch and told us to write notes because we would need it if we had a follow-up interview (which is one on one at a location nearest to us, a half hour before the business actually opens, which I find extremely odd). During the meeting, they told us that the job was marketing and then mentioned the parent company (Cuba Inspires), and used name-dropping to make it sound better than I suspect it is. The person told us that the owner works with clients like The Simpsons to help them obtain travel to Cuba and said that we would potentially meet with them and other guys like that (this was a big red flag to me). The website stated that the company got started in the UK about 10 years ago, but that the US office started in 2020 (and claims 2019). She also said that there are offices in Australia, Colombia, Canada, UK, etc, but I found no evidence of this whatsoever. At the end of the call, she told us to expect a follow-up email regarding a second interview, saying that we needed to respond between 3pm and 6pm to secure a spot for the interview. No questions were allowed during the first interview and they never respond to emails regarding questions asked. I strongly suspect this company runs under multiple names and uses the same basic hiring practices elsewhere, under other identities. I had also noted this of interest: I searched for this company through OSINT databases and blogs and found very little information. The website (http://www.goinspirechange.com) looks extremely fake, like a stock website. The address (8201 Corporate Drive, Suite 250, Hyattsville, MD, 20785) is questionable, as there are reportedly a number of other companies in the same building. According to thesters, the company website is hiding their domain info. It describes the owner as being a Silicon valley group called "Loop, Inc." (aka Loop Now Technologies, Inc), and their website also doesn't exist. They have what appears to be a few fake reviews on Google (the only ones with commentary are negative), and the website Google links to is also fake. The 4 employees listed on LinkedIn for 2017 have no background in media relations. All of the emails were signed with "Emma" (which I found on another website talking about a similar name, same - name), but none of the LinkedIn employees are named Emma. Clicking 'apply' on any of the posts listed at http://www.goinspirechange.com/opportunities/# goes nowhere. The section called "You Will Be In Charge Of" on LinkedIn doesn't seem to change much, and all of the qualifications are the same no matter what the job is--I find this very suspicious. The parent company for those two companies is "Cuba Inspires." Cuba Inspires' website also does not exist Its Twitter has 5 posts, none of which actually belong to the company Its Twitter hasn't been active since 2017 and has almost no posts Its Facebook is a page that someone created, not the company's. I am hoping I am wrong about this company but unfortunately, I don't think I am. I think they've avoided detection until now through a number of non-disclosure agreements (which are legal but not illegal) and changing their name frequently. They may also be a company called the Young Entrepreneurs Academy. I didn't give them any personal information or money, but I'm concerned that others may have.

They have my name, address, email, and phone. I took photos of the entire conversation.
Asked to be a secret lover. They sent a check for 1950 to buy gift cards.

We make the process of supplying  various offshore operations with equipment, general supplies, machines, vehicles, oil pipes, parts, tools, engines and many more as easy and cost-effective as possible. Founded in 2002 we are currently headquartered in Stockholm (Sweden) and expanding over U.S (2020) and Canada (2021). POSITION Project Supervisor (Job ID: 0) JOB STATUS: Full-Time, W2  WORKING HOURS: 9-00 a.m - 5-00 p.m, local time  SALARY (FIXED): $92,000.00 - $95,000.00 BENEFITS: medical, dental and vision insurance (for you and 1 family member), 401K program "50 of the first 6%", FMLA and PTO, performance reports POSTED: 2020-06-08 POSITION SUMMARY - Manages all aspects of equipment projects, from beginning to end, with direct responsibility for project execution  - Leads a team, or teams to accomplish specific objectives in a given time frame and with limited resources  - Responsible for the administration, implementation and management of equipment lease/finance projects  - Accounting for assigned projects,  scope of work, schedule and budget  RESPONSIBILITIES - Responsible for the completion of assigned projects and customer satisfaction. - Plans and manages assigned projects, establishes schedules and project parameters and sets procedures to accomplish system objectives. - meetings with customers and their representatives, including owners, contractors, contractors, and field support staff. - Controls expenses by monitoring assigned project budget. TRAINING PROGRAM: paid, $2,500-4,500  TRAINING PROGRAM DETAILS: all managers are expected to complete a 4 week paid entry level management training, you will receive one new study every day and a test for them each day. You 'n't have to pay for anything or involve your personal funds into this. Training 'n't take you more than 20 minutes every day, easy to combine with your full time job.  Your Payment depends on results of four training tests and the Final test. You will receive guaranteed $2,500 (via cash or direct deposit), but it can be $4,500 if you have over  average test scores. You will be invited to come to our New York office for a short introduction course once you pass 4 weeks of training and the final test after that, on 5th week. This is when you will receive a formal job offer letter. We cover all expenses for travel and a week-long stay. Please reply with any comment and I'll send you next steps and application forms to apply for position. Feel free to contact me if you have any questions. Thanks in advance and looking forward to hearing from you soon, Michelle Anderson, Human Resources: +18337151771 Metropolitan Supply Network, Inc. 1325 6th Avenue, New York, NY 10019 Metropolitansn.com

After posting on Facebook, I came across a part-time job as a Virtual Assistant for Matt Klette's Sweet Treats. As a college student this seemed like a pretty good deal so I sent in my application. I then received an email several weeks later saying I would be a good candidate for the job. In this email they asked for me to fill out a "job application" with normal information like name, address, phone number. They also asked that I include a picture of my driver's license. I sent it, and immediately received an email with bizarre language and slang which then led me to believe that this was a dream. Don't be like me. Do not send your driver's license over email to a company you know nothing about. I also found Facebook pages and other websites stating that this job offer is a deal, and if you accept the job the checks will bounce, and they are most likely trying to get into your bank account.

I was initially contacted by email saying they had seen my resume on one of the job search sites and wanted to interview me. He conducted an interview including detailed questions over the app Telegram and after an hour or so he said he'd discuss with his team and they came back saying they'd like to offer me a job. I was just as I'd been unemployed for almost a year. He detailed the position and everything it would contain. He said the company was based in Italy but has a location in the US and was going to commission a building in Los Angeles for March 1 so it would be a remote position until then. I was sent a job offer letter, along with a business code of conduct and the government paperwork for employment. I reported to Miss Bionda (supposedly) every morning and completed several tasks (writing research reports). I was sent checks via email to deposit to my bank account and use partially as payment and partially toward purchasing necessary equipment. Everything was always extremely detailed and seemed completely legitimate. The first check was frozen in my bank account and they apologized, said he was working personally with the chief of accounting going over their weekly finances to get the issue resolved and that they'd send a check from a different one of the financial institutions they work with. The second check cleared and they had me send one payment through Zelle, and they said the other payments had to go through the app Zengo by purchasing it and sending it as payment to the vendors accounts. They sent another check a few days later for additional equipment and by the time I had deposited it the second check was showing as frozen as well, even though it'd been showing as available earlier. My account was used multiple times but I wanted to believe it wasn't a dream because I needed a job so badly. I ended up getting asked to put an additional $980 on my credit card. I only fully realized the truth when my bank froze my entire account pending an investigation. I let  out sayo  know and he hasn't responded since.

I applied for a job on indeed.com for a software engineer position at HemaSource Inc. which had vague information on the position. This didn't phase me since I am applying to 10+ jobs a week. After applying, I received instructions to begin the interview/screening process by making another email address my basic info (name, phone, and city). They also asked for availability which made me assume I would have a phone call with them. Instead, they send me a word document with interview questions for me to fill out. There was no request for secure information at this time and I thought this would lead to an actual interview over the phone. Instead, I send the completed word document. They tell me that the board will decide whether to hire me and about 1 hour later they tell me that I got the job. The offer was way too good for someone in my position. That is when I realized that this likely wasn't a real offer. They did mention they would send me a check to buy supplies for a home office (I'm guessing this is how the kid gets money). I immediately stopped correspondence with the email chain and looked up the contact info (which wasn't included in any of the emails) on the real company's website. After talking with me, they confirmed with me that the company wasn't actively looking for any software engineers. The emails included two names of actual employees (I confirmed this with him), each only mentioned once or twice in a weird sort of way. The real company told me that I was the second person to call about this issue.

I received an email from someone saying that I put my resume on their website and after seeing my resume they were impressed. They gave details of the company and said to download the new app and speak to the hiring manager for a resume. The company that I was interviewed for is a large company in Italy called GSE S.p.A. They were saying that they were opening an office in Albany, NY on March 22nd. However, that company is not opening an office in that area. That company is only in Italy and is not opening anywhere else in the world. They also stole the identity of a person that does work at that company to make it seem like they are dead. They stole the identity of William V    . This is what I received in the email: Dear Prospective Employee, Our Talent Acquisition Consultant has received, reviewed, and evaluated the resume you posted, and you have been shortlisted for an online interview because we strongly believe your skill set meets the desired criteria. The open positions are Data Entry Clerk, Content Marketing Manager, Administrative Assistant, Sales Associate, IT Manager, and Customer Service/Call Center Representative. (If you already have an existing Telegram account, you may proceed with it as well for the online interview). The company will ship products to your personal address and they want you to open the box and inspect the product and test it out.  The company gives you the labels to re-ship and the packages arrive to me using a different name then mine but still have my address.  The pay was $2000 base with additional $40 a package. I applied for a work at home customer service position with this company called Nference Inc on indeed. They contacted me by email(photo attached). I never applied for a job that required a certain application but I figured because of the unusual circumstances, I would have to proceed. The interview process was simple questions and Answers. Seemed pretty basic and structured. Second part was Payment and Pay, he asked about hours, time range, pay interval  weekly or weekly, pay method  check direct deposit, bank name, and if I was in the military. I didn't think anything of it so I gave it to him. After the interview the minister asked me to "hold online because he needed to forward the conversation to the head department to confirm and enable them to see if  I'm  committed and good for the job." Within about 15 minutes, I've been confirmed for the position. Then he told me that the company will provide me a apple laptop with fast internet connection, mini office equipment supplies and all the programs Im going to need for the job.  For every filling/ registration, he proceeds to ask me for my Full Name, Full Address, Phone/Cell number, Sex, and Email. At this point, I am so excited that I found a job, I didn't even think about the consequences so I gave it to him. On the next message he says I will get started right away and I needed to set up a mini office and the company will mail me a check that will pay for it. Here is where I am so used to the fact that I will be getting that stuff for free and that I will have my little office so I said 'yes' the address was my bank and same for my bank information. The next message, he said that I will be getting a check within the week to start working soon. He continues to say that he will update me and to 'bear' with him. The check will be used to purchase from an affiliated vendor who provides them. The following message he emphasizes that "All equipment and software are to be purchased from the company accredited vendor who they have been buying from for years..." He continues to mention the check and how to appear my name on it. Then he contacted me again and told me to report back the next day at 8am my time. After that conversation I felt something in my gut especially about the check. I looked up the name of the company and found a website ( https://nference.ai/ ). I look to see and make sure it because it seemed to be too good to be true. I found an address and tried to match the address on Google maps. The company name does not appear on the maps in Cambridge, Massachusetts. I even looked up the new name and it didn't show up. I was getting panicked so I called the Mayor of Cambridge, Massachusetts to see if she have heard of that company she also gave the number of the Consumer Council of Cambridge, Massachusetts. They both said they will check into it  and call me back the next day. I did more research and learned that there are such thing of job as and there are 'robots' that are programmed to do it. I had no idea! I didn't expect that Indeed.com would have listing of fake companies. So I prepared my self with questions to ask the next morning. I texted him at 8am he sent me a text that didn't really end a question so I waited for a response. I wanted to see if it existed but didn't get response 12 minutes later. He wanted to confirm my information for my materials. I said I had a few questions. I asked him where exactly the "Headquarters" was to confirm the website and it was in fact the same address and website I found but not located on Google maps. I mentioned that I could not pin point the location of the building because it didn't have a building sign on those maps. He continued about issuing the check. I asked how long the company has been around and he said in 2013. In my head I said to myself  if they been around that long they could have at least had a sign on the building. This may not be a legitimate company. I wanted to get personal and asked him "how long he been with the company?" and he said 5 years and only recently transferred as a Sales Manager in the Cambridge, Massachusetts location. He still promised that I would be home for the check. I asked "what department he transfer from?" and he said "why all this questions?". I said "I ca- ask questions?" any ways seems he was getting frustrated but he still wanted to confirm my address. I told him that I was no longer interested in the position. I was about to send another text to say sorry and he erased all the messages and removed me from the conversation. But I have parts of the whole conversation (just once) before he deleted them. Joe Tartabini (Twitter profile: https://www.linkedin.com/in/joe-tartabini-32aa591b2/) asked me on line a few weeks ago about various jobs available at his company, AT INTERNET SOLUTIONS (short for Applied Technology Solutons Inc.). After some discussion, he referred me to another band member, Mike, to interview with off of LinkedIn. Helene Le Pape (online Page: https://www.linkedin.com/in/helenelepape/) contacted me via a messenger, claiming she was the Deputy Director for AT INTERNET. She never called or used video calls, but only voice messages. Upon each time of contact with her, Joe would also message me and tell me that I needed to be on Skype to talk with someone at that exact time, or even after I was already chatting with her so they are clearly working together. After a very unusual interview process and described everything, she gave me an offer for a remote Project Manager job and I accepted. I did research on the company, read the Wikipedia pages about it, and found the Vice Director's bio and photo on the AT INTERNET website which matched the one on her Skype profile. Everything looked real. I asked many questions and they responded with complete sentences so it did not appear to be like many online sites where bad grammar is present and no other information can be found online. One of the first major red flags was when I dialed the phone number for their corporate New York office and the phone rang for an unusually long time, ultimately leading to a generic call, "the person you're calling is not available" then an abrupt stop to leave a message. How does a corporate company not have a phone menu and or detailed email message? The next red flag was that they required me to pay for my background check. I was instructed to buy a visa gift card and then send the card information to her Secretary. He appeared to be operating from one of the main offices but her secretary was located in the New York office. That didn't make sense but again, I continued. I decided that this was safer than sharing any personal financial information at the time, and more.  Next, I filled out tax paperwork, I-9, and W-4 forms, including personal information and but was never asked for direct deposit information for future payment. Shortly after this, I was asked for my credit card institution for  number and password, so the company could give me "a payment for company equipment." I argued with Karen about my refusal to show my credentials and demanded she contacts me via phone call on my cell phone immediately. She claimed her secretary would reach out. I never got a call. No one has followed up since. It was at that moment that I realized it was a dream. I am taking necessary actions now to protect myself and my information but also making numerous reports on their fraud. I have saved the entirety of my conversations with both Joe and Peter for future evidence if needed. Please investigate their profiles and AT INTERNET SOLUTIONS before someone else falls victim to their charm. The company may be real and these people are posing as the PR team or the whole thing could be fake. It is unclear.

The message stated "Good day, I am Mrs. Chantal Espinosa (phone number 910-933-5022). I am calling you in response to your resume of an Administrative Assistant/Virtual Assistant advertised online. I will like to proceed with your interview with you if interested." I agreed to move forward that very same day (Monday, January 18, 2021) I was told to download their app and add Mr. Tim Kelly the company hiring manager's personal interview link. My interview was scheduled the following day (Tuesday, Jan. 19, 2021 at 9am). Before the start of the interview Tim sent me the company website (www.makrocare.com) and told me "I was required to take 5 minutes of my time to read about the company, then let him know when I was done to proceed with the interview. The interview was different and than I expected. All communication and questions was done through text through the email app. After the interview was completed, Tim Kelly, said to me "Well, you have done well so far and you seem like a perfect fit for this position. I need you to hold online because I need to forward our conversation to the Head, to enable them to see if you are committed and good for this job. I need you to hold back online". When Tim came back to me he said, "For your consideration stand, you have good news, the good news is you've just been confirmed qualified for this position. You are welcome to "Take Care". You are now given a chance to show your Commitment, Charisma, Diligence and be a Productive employee. I have our whole conversation on my phone and just because somehow he deleted the messages from his end. I have been speaking with Tim everyday, I was told I would undergo 1 week training and orientation. Tim told me to email my full name, a copy of my drivers license, my home address, phone number, to the company CEO, Mrs. Kathryn B. Gundersen at HR@makrocareinc.com to enable superiors to enter them into the Company's Register for proper documentation. I provided all information and received an offer letter to sign and return. I received a text (through telegraph) from Tim and an email from me saying to get started with my job I was told they would need to send me a check to purchase software to use for this job. I was sent a list of software and equipment needed. On Jan. 21, 2021, I received a check that was sent overnight via FedEx, as soon as the check arrived I received a text message from Tim Kelly saying, "I need you to open your package now and verify the amount on the check and let me know the actual amount sent to you now. This is when he told me to proceed to deposit the check right away into my account so I could start my orientation. I was completely shocked by the dollar amount of $5,000.00. He stated "Once the funds are available I will refer you to the local vendor you are to purchase your working equipment from to enable you start your training and orientation immediately. You are required to email/text me a picture of the deposit slip for record purpose. I sent Tim the deposit slip. The following day (January 22, 2021) Tim text me asking if funds were available and to take $4800.00 from my account and go to Bitcoin ATM to deposit and buy Bitcoin and make it available to the vendor's (software vendor) network address info that Tim provided me with. He sent me the online wallet address - code to scan at the Bitcoin machine. Tim asked me to let him know when I was at the ATM and he will walk me through the steps. This is something I've never done before. I asked him if this was a deal, he seemed surprised that I asked him that but assured me that this was no scheme and this was it for my now new job. I said to him I sure hope this is. and I'm not comfortable doing this and I would not do this again. Once this was all done, Tim told me they will send me a "new HP Pro 3 or Apple Macbook Pro MJLQ2LL/A 15-inch laptop, whatever I prefer" it would have all software installed and other needed equipment would be shipped to me.  He confirmed the Bitcoin deposit of $4800.00 was received and told me he will contact me the next morning (Sunday) about shipping. This conversation was on June 22, 2021. I didn't hear anything from him on Sunday but didn't get to concern because it was the weekend, but when I still didn't hear from Tim on Monday, I got concerned. Today (today) I contacted Tim saying "I have been waiting to hear from him, and all he said was good morning, how was my night. Later in the afternoon I texted him back saying "I'm curious to know what's the status of this job" He has not responded. I saw online an advertisement for making money by advertising a major company on my vehicle. I filled out the form, just interested in what this was about and how much it would pay. That was about 2-3 weeks ago. Today, I received a "Priority Mail" from  NBC, representing themselves as advertising for Breyers Ice Cream. Inside was a letter on plain white paper giving me instruction on how to deposit  the enclosed check for $2850.50, the place was Trans-Overseas Corporation,28000 Park Road, North Highway 48174. Upon reading the letter, it was obviously NOT from Breyers Ice Cream, as there was no professional stationary, and looked like a simple computer printer made it.  I doubted the legitimacy due to repeated errors and double repeats in the same sentence, and also the fact that after receiving the check, I was to pay the "sale of the car wrap" $2000, the remainder I was to keep as my payment for advertising. Additionally, the total amount of the check would not be available "right away", so this was also a red flag.  Upon looking up Trans-Overseas Corp, it is a Customs Bureau, Freight Transfer, Warehousing and Logistics service, not an advertising agency.  Obvious cash, fake check, and attempt at getting me to pay for something, BEWARE

The work environment and climate must support the well-being, development, and initiative of staff to achieve full participation and performance excellence. Okay? Great

She encouraged me to download a mobile app called Telegram. I did and I connected with an interview from what seemed to be the profile of "the company." The interview was a bit unprofessional, with a lot spelling errors. I thought they may be foreign so, although it was a red flag it didn't seem too incredibly out of the ordinary.
