I received a text message advertising an employment opportunity as a Secret Worker at my local bakery. The text was sent to my phone number ending in  3056, and it was a group (SMS) text to my number and the four preceding phone numbers (i.e.  3052- 3055). The structure of the phone numbers used and two words in the web address and company name caused me to think this was an online game. The company name was spelled Target, not Miller. The web address spelled "evaluation" as 'evaluation.' I don't know if this indicates the player is unfamiliar with English or "similar yet different" terms are used to allow such offers to use such filters.

I agreed, thinking I would contacted for training to be a mystery wrapped around the holiday season. A couple of weeks later I received a check for $2340 and a letter with instructions to deposit the check into my account and take the cash and get 4 deposit cards to load $500 on each. Then go the the stores listed and spend $500 while surveying the stores  about and rate,  if there were any  bad services but  if the attendant was  too rude,  and on a  large scale of 1 to 10 how fast and efficient was the service done. I was to then mail the evaluation report to dennis.ortiz90@icloud.com. Then I was supposed to mail the credit cards to a public address that would be provided to me after the  last survey report request  was received. I was to  also keep the remaining $300 as my payout. And the $15.80 and $24.20 was to be used for gas or transportation to and from these stores. When I looked at the company's name on the check it was a company called  the Associated Developer's Concrete Inc. -  - which had nothing to do with Intouch Insight  or being a mystery company. So I called the bank that the check was from and gave them the account number. Of course this account was NOT valid. The bank's'said  you good job you  for calling us before you deposited this big check into your account. Clearly they were familiar with these types of stuff! I went online and discovered that this shit has been going on for a while. Please believe  anything too good to be true usually is - I just didn't think it would come as a  new job opportunity but  in times like these where people are losing jobs every day  and these monsters are relying on people about s vulnerabilities. I was reached out to through Indeed after applying to a job listing for an Assistant. They offered me an interview for that day and I accepted. In between the offer for the interview and the time of the interview I tried to find information on the company online so I could be prepared. I couldn't find anything. I was told the website is under construction so I was given a brief highly "technical" summary of the company. I believe he used the words on purpose to convince me so I wouldn't ask too many crazy questions. In hopes that it wasn't a dream, I had my father drive me to the office and stay in the parking lot. I was met in the main reception hall of the office complex and had a very simple interview in the conference room. He did not ask many typical questions and actually tend to stumble on his words. At the end of the interview, he offers me the job and I accept. I was not asked to sign anything, nor would I if I had been asked. He shows me the office we will be working out of and it is being painted and has no furniture or windows. When I came home I was still suspicious so I continued trying to find more evidence of the company. It is not listed on BBB or on the Secretary of State databases. I did not find a Linkedin for either company. I found a Linkedin In for the man who interviewed me and his wife but both were very empty. I sent him a thank you email and asked where I could find more information. He replied with "I'm not sure" and his email did not have a signature at the bottom. I have attached a version of the email correspondence. Happy to provide the other benefits related.
I had several conversations via email and I gave my name and home address.  The mother was due to have a baby and would be getting two dogs on 12/1/20 at which time I would be paid 400 a week.  My school Suffolk County Community College then sent out an emergency alert about the pet-sitting.
I did not fall for this shit, but wanted to report it so that other people don't fall for it. I reached out through Indeed to this company. The indeed listing was under a different name than the company that contacted me back, which should have been my first red flag, and the hiring process was way too fast than any other company I have applied to before. The company seemed odd to me from the start, as their address was not their warehouse, but rather another companies warehouse. I had assumed they were sharing a warehouse but could not confirm this. This plan was super elaborate and they had a whole website that appeared illegal. Obviously, a lot of money went into this as they had an automated email system, multiple emails under the company name, multiple people working for the firm, different phone numbers under the same area code, websites with proper privacy policy and terms, an employee website made for the work they had assigned to me, and a shipping system that made and sent shipping codes to me to send out packages. My role was a package manager and quality control inspector, I would receive packages from the mail or pick them up from a location and send them out after confirming they were genuine. I assumed this was a very successful drop shipping company and management never received the packages, therefore, I was the middle man for the company to make sure items were the real deal. It seemed a little silly that they were offering so much for a simple task, but they were not asking for money from me, so I hoped it was real. I received a bunch of packages that cost a lot and saw some inconsistencies with what they told me in the training video. I am not sure how they bought these packages, possibly with stolen bank account info. I let it slide and ate up the excuses they gave me, which were reasonable and not far between. The reason why this man got me is that they never asked for money or a loan from me, and made sure I did not have to use money on shipping supplies as well. I did spend a little bit of money but was promised compensation for my expenses. Luckily, I did not pay for a direct payment system so they don't have access to my bank account, but my SS number was compromised from the w-4 form they asked of me. After a month of working for the company, I found myself locked out of my employee account and right when I should have received money for my time there. I have had no contact from the company since then and have accepted the loss, though I will be very involved with trying everything I can to the people who have orchestrated this whole scheme. Very few reviews exist of this company and I am sure they will just change the name of their company to start again. Every time I looked at the creation date of their website or eve their blog profile, the creation date was literally a few days after they contacted me. Which was a massive red flag. Please take down their profile or flag them as a failure, it was a complete waste of a month and I lost out on several other genuine employee opportunities while working for them.

The position was a work from home position where I would be selling packages via FedEx or UPS, I would open and do a quality check and fill out their online form about my findings on each package. Each package inspected and shipped to their customer would be $40. Per week I was receiving about 5-6 packages a week. Each package received was something very expensive such as new apple watches, electronics, high end phones, etc. (This is another reason I thought this was a legitimate company) After a 30 day preparation period I was told I would then be considered for a full time position there. When I would email the manager about pay or packages, I would not get a response. The position promised a vote after 30 days. I stuck to this job for 30 days and on my last day they kicked me out of their fake portal where I was not able to log in anymore to view all my packages or pay. I am asked to ship something - often electronics - to an address domestic or overseas. You send off the items, but your payment never arrives. You've been robbed, and you may have just helped others move illegally obtained goods.

I then had a "interview" where they asked me the following questions: Are you currently employed? What carrier network do you operate with? If given a choice, would you rather manage or be managed? What do you understand by the terms ''Privacy'' and ''Code of Conduct''? What is your last job Income? What are you most proud of? I was approved for the position shortly after answering those questions and was told I would receive an e-mail with the job acceptance letter and a blank page to fill out. Following this I asked when I would be starting so I could give my current job notice due to a time frame conflict of when I had to log on and my schedule at my current job and he didn't give me a straight answer. He would only say "Yes that is not a problem, You will be undergoing a week of training and orientation which will commence as soon as you have all the working materials and you are rest assured that you will be paid for it. Okay" They then asked me whether I wanted to be paid weekly or bi-weekly and what bank I used.  He Then went on to say the following "I need you to provide me with the following information correctly: Full name: Address: City: State: Name: Cell: To enable my secretary enter them into the Company's Register for proper documentation. It is also required by the Accounting Department for the filing of the check. Some of the information will also appear on your job offer letter which will be sent to you first thing tomorrow morning." Now granted I understand that it is normally something that is confirmed during an acceptance but I was a bit skeptical and that's when I found someone had already reported them once before. I responded with "I mean no offense but all of that information is on my resume. With everything going these days, I am hesitate to enter too much personal information about myself." To which he responded with "Yes we have your details on your resume but we need to confirm from you." I have made no further contact with this individual.

This was posted on a page group for parents and parents of dependent adults on 11/16/2020. I'm looking for a work@home opportunity. My mother in law, trying to help in the job search, texted me the "script" that was used: Hello! I currently work from home for A CORPORATION COMPANY We are currently looking for a few as an age to join our team! 5 days a week ( weekends off ) Starting rate is $25/- Paid weekly! We are looking for immediate hire, feel free to pm me for more information. Please note this is a wonderful secondary job. Great hours for parents who need to be off for their children activities! I mean Cathy Ketring. I'd asked questions, and her responses were immediately a few seconds later. I was suspicious because the responses were pretty good for how fast she replied. Like they were typing and editing responses from a script. Some of the replies include: -This is strictly an online and flexible work from home job that the working hours are flexible and you can choose to work from anywhere of your choice the pay is $25 hour,training is $15 hour and will be get payment every weekend via direct deposit or credit card and the Minimum amount you can work a week is 20 .  Maximum of 45hrs.if you are employed you are going to be working as a full employee and not an independent contractor. Reply YES if interested!!! Source:Data Entry Work From Home Job Duties  and  Responsibilities 1. analyze, review, and interpret all lease data before entry into the database. 2. Ensure all data is accurately and quickly entered. 3. Review all documents that come in for accuracy (this makes the data entry people's jobs easier). Okay Can you handle this effectively if you're being trained towards it? You would undergo a week training from your training supervisor. During that time, he will let you know how to work with the company-specific programs with much accuracy's and other data entry tasks you will need to get done. Your training will be conducted online through your phone or laptop. -You will undergo an online interview with the company hiring agent now. When I mentioned this new exciting opportunity, all my friends said they thought it was a dream. I looked it up  and  sure enough, it was a card. I called my bank immediately. I never bought the gift cards. I'm not exactly clear on how this shit works. But if seems to be to good to be true, it usually is.

I told him that my bank would not accept the check, and that I was not going to use my funds, and wished to speak to his manager. He gave an excuse for why his manager was not available, and then said that I was not following his directions, and said that he was going to have to cut me off. He then gave me a story about buying my equipment for a "company certified vendor" and asked if I was familiar with Zelle (a fast way to send money). He quoted that $1000 was needed for the materials. I finally cut to the quick: The companies name is on none of this paperwork or the check. Large companies such as Temonos would use company orders, company checks, and ship using the companies heading on the packing slips. And, if you were from Temonos, you would have used a service such as that to interview someone. So that you and the person being interviewed could see and speak to each other. You seem to be more interested in my getting this check or my spending my own money to buy equipment and software. This program does not affect your present activity if you have one. Register today to get $600. Also you can earn as much as $3,100 monthly. JOB DESCRIPTION A bank check (ranging from $3,530 - $4,650) depending on our competitors, will be handed out to you via USPS for the first task. The payment covers all expenses including your salary) STEP 1: Cash or deposit the payment at your bank. Funds will be available for withdrawal instantly or within 24-48 hours for you to carry out the survey at the stores. Target, Best Buy, 7-Eleven, Office Depot, Sears, Lowes, Target, Rite Aid, Subway, Pick n Save, Fred Meyer, Winston-Dixie, Stop !  Shop, Shaws, Ahold, Kmart, Target, Sports and all.. A lot of customers have reported insufficient gift cards and the amount paid to evaluate the gift cards is not equal to the amount loaded on the cards (especially higher denominations) in some outlets. Our need to act is based on these reports and complaints filed annually to our head office. STEP 3: After  evaluation, open and take each card out of the pack. Capture clear images of the front and back of each card and send to us via email for information. We want to verify and look for errors on the cards after evaluation at these stores to ensure customers get value for their funds. After thorough examination of the cards with the help of your quality feedback, It will be reprinted, reproduced and sent to the holding company by just altering the last four digits as long as the serial number is then put back on the shelf. It is as good as buying off the counter and replacing. I was contacted about an opening at Nuvo USA via email on 10/26/2020. They started to have job openings for Data Entry and Administrative Assistants. I am looking for an administrative position right now, and I posted my resume at multiple job sites. I believe that is how they got my contact info. I was asked to interview via the Twitter app, and I did so on 10/28/2020. The interview was comprehensive. They asked the same detailed questions as many legitimate interviews. They used the real Nuvo logo on Telegram and email. They used the names of people who work at the real site. They gave specific details about the job, and after an hour or so, said I was hired. They asked for my name, address, email, and my bank's name but did not ask for other identifying or financial information on Telegram. The hourly rate for the work was high, but not out of the realm of possibility, given my experience and the administrative salaries in my area. They made me start paperwork, including an I-9, W-4, direct deposit form, offer letter, and a long, legitimate-looking company Code of Conduct. In the new app, they indicated that they would send me funds to pay for the equipment I would need to do the job. Unfortunately, I did fill out all the start paperwork and send it to them. However, when I received a check from them, I knew it was a trap. The check looked suspicious  it came with a strange letter with no company logo. The letter demanded that I send a copy of the deposit slip when I put the check in the bank. At that point, I put a freeze on my credit with all three guys. Today (11/2/2020), according to my "company contact" through the Twitter app, I was supposed to deposit the check, set aside $150 as a "sign-on bonus," and send them a deposit slip. They also asked that I let them know when the funds were available in my account. I closed my bank account. I am usually not an easy person to read. This one was very thorough and convincing, and I am just desperate for a job right now. I should have caught on when they wanted to interview via a dating app, even though there are a few companies who conduct interviews that way.

Then once I signed the papers and handed the forms back he said that was all for that day and to contact him on Tuesday at 8am for further details, so I did the next day. I was told that a check would be sent to me and I should receive it by the next morning and it came by fed ex that morning. So he told me to deposit the check in my account and wait for it to clear and he asked me did I think it would clear in 2 days and I said they will release some but the rest 'n't clear for 4 days. So he told me to take $250 for a sign on bonus when the check clear. The money was suppose to have been for software and equipment for the job, so that I can work from home. So once the check cleared he told me to setup a new go account and I did and then he told me to buy $3900 in currency, that didn't go through because I couldn't get pass the security, so then he said to try $2800 and that didn't go through either so the $3,982 check was credited back to my account and then the next morning my bank was getting some message in their system saying refer to maker so my bank took the check and my $50 was gone also and my account was returned in the amount of $199.48. I had to pay the bank back by using money in my savings account. After that the man's personal account was deleted and I heard nothing from him again.

I received a call about setting up an interview with this company at 10 am on the dot. I am a resident of Atlanta, and I first received a call from New Jersey right at 10 am. I declined it, and then immediately got a new call from an Atlanta number. Being it was an Atlanta number, and I have been applying to a number of jobs in the area, I answered. The woman greeted me, and explained she saw my resume and they were interested in me. The job was a marketing job, and when she described the responsibilities it was exactly the type of jobs I have been applying for. She caught me off guard when she called, and I was naive to agree to set up an interview. It was mid-level marketing position, but if you look on their website there is no job listing. After we set up the interview time, I received an email confirming our phone call. I felt this was a trap after I agreed to it and hung up. When I called the phone number a different marketing company showed up, but they had the same address. I was contacted by another employment agent back in town using the same address. Another red flag was that the email started with "hello" followed by the company name. They originally called me at 6:30 am that they wanted to interview me, and then called me at 10 am when I did not answer. Everything was done through Google Voice.   This is the email: Dear           , Hope you are doing great! I am pleased to compliment you on your successful completion of our hiring process! We warmly welcome you to Uniwest Logistics company, where you will be working with some of the foremost leaders in our industry. We look forward to the contributions you will make to maintain our company's reputation for excellence and dedication to customer care. Attached to this message, you'll find a Pre-Employment Agreement. This Agreement ensures that once you have successfully completed your trial period with us, you will then be eligible for long-term, full-time employment at the company. Next Steps: 1. Read the Pre-Agreement carefully, paying attention to the details provided relevant to this position. 2. Print and sign the last page of the agreement, or sign via e-signature. 3. Return the signature page to me today or tomorrow. Training Details: The new Training Manager (Mr. Anthony Mayer) will be sending you an email or tomorrow (10/22/20), with all of your training materials, so please be sure to keep a copy for it and check your bulk/junk mail folder just in case it gets routed to a folder other than your name. It is crucial that you send a confirmation email to Mr. Mayer immediately so he can be sure you received this.
Fear of a Quality Control Inspector job being offered as a "work from home" opportunity.  They will ask you to send your resume and ask a few simple questions and then you are officially hired!   They will then email you a cute and well done video to watch on how the whole process works.  It's very simple.  You will be contacted by multiple people via email and sometimes text message.  Then you are to send them a copy of your drivers license to verify who you are.  Once you are "approved" you will be sent a link to setup your Dashboard, which is the way they will communicate to you, keep track of incoming and outgoing packages to be shipped.  Everything seemed pretty quiet, except some of the phone calls that I received from supposedly someone in Human Resources, Shipping Manager, My Supervisor.  the other red flag was how much money they were willing to pay for this position.  A guarantee of $2800/month, plus $50/package that is shipped on time, and then some other money, as well.  Oh, and 4 weeks paid vacation!  Wow!  I finally did my own research and discovered that the company was only about a month old and could not be found registered with the Better Business Bureau.   I then called the cops and inquired if they had encountered any type of case like this and the nice lady read something to me that sounded pretty accurate.  Therefore, I decided to report this company so that those who are desperately looking for work and want to work from home would not be scared into thinking this was a great work opportunity.
There is someone posing as people who work for the Sinclair Broadcast Group.  They are even linking things to the actual company.  They went through the entire interview process with me over chat and offered me a job.  I felt it was better because they had no picture, but they had a lot of details including a bank account with 700+ followers.  At the end they told me I got the graphic design job, and sent me forms to fill out that looked very official for the Sinclair Broadcast Group that looked like they could be from the company itself.  They were ordering me to sign and return them but I wasn't about to send someone I had never seen before my social security number, etc.  I asked for a video call and she pretended to set one up and said something like "don't let your stress keep you from getting a job that can help you and your family" and that's when I knew for sure it was a call because no serious person hiring is going to say that and put pressure on you to sign something when you don't feel comfortable doing so.  The name they used with me was Melissa Yim. They first contacted me with the name ofn in an email telling me to get in touch with Mrs. Melissa Yim. I just saw today that they are using a possible real person's identity who works at Sinclair Broadcast Group called Sharon Pickeral. She does have a picture on her account.  They way they told me to contact them was through the Telegram app using Twitter and that name was Melissa Yim yesterday and has changed to Sharon Pickeral today. I hope this helps whoever they are trying to find today.
I was contact by Adriana Mancini about working with a company named the  Dons group put  out in Italy. She is very professional in communication. Here is an example Please accept our most sincere congratulations! I am very glad to see you join our friendly team. Since you filled out the application and signed the employment agreement, I will be in charge of your training period in order to help you master all skills necessary for this position. So from this point forward I will be your personal manager helping you during your probation. I will be in charge of teaching and guiding you, and providing answers to your questions should you have any. I recommend you to save my email address in the list of your trusted contacts to prevent my messages from going into your email folder. Since your training will be online in real time, I will stay in touch, control all your work and help you understand all instructions. I will call you periodically to discuss various details so save my number as well (478) 220-7001. Very soon we will start your training. Of course before we start I will call you in order to explain you everything and discuss all information. But in brief, within two days you will receive your first assignment and start working. I will email you detailed information about the task and step-by-step instructions. You should take responsibility for all assignments given and read my instructions carefully. You should give the feedback (confirmment of instructions) and ask questions should you have any. In the meantime, please confirm your name, contact number and full email address (including the apartment # if any) because this information will be used by me for our regular on-line and mail correspondence with you, and therefore the email address will be used in order to send you salary checks: Well I did the first assignment which was basic research on my local real estate market. Then the second assignment came around. She wanted me to cash this check that I was supposed to be receiving from a company and then send her a portion of it but take 5% of it out for me and sent her the rest. I had asked the bank when the money would be available and they advised me that as soon as I saw it in my account it was available. Unfortunately my bank did not tell me that even though the money was in my account that doesn't mean the check cleared.  So I sent them money $1660 using paper currency on a Friday and on Monday I found out my account was in the negative because the check bounced.  So this day was a loss of  almost $800 of my own money and the balance I owe my bank over $890.  I told Adriana that the check bounced and she told me to send my bank statements.  My bank told me that this was a card and not to send it.  She stays in contact with you calls you emails you. So be careful if you see this persons name.

 I recently updated my resume on Indeed and my profile on LinkedIn as I am in the market for a new place of employment. On October 15, I received a text message from 3128091887 @ He greeting me by my full name asking me how I was doing. I didn't recognize the number and asked who it was. The person responded and said his name was Mr. Bali Sanghera, hiring manager of Star OUTiCO company and that he was calling me because my resume had been provided to him and wanted me to schedule an online job listing about the available positions and to do an interview with him.    I replied and asked him what and where are these positions. He didn't reply until early the next morning. I thought that was odd, but then I called the company and saw that it was located in Bath, UK. They are 6 hours ahead of us so I figured that was the reason for the odd time. The text said it was a remote position for an LVN located in Killeen TX and that I was advised to follow instructions for more details of the company.    I searched his name on LinkedIn and found a profile that matches. The person's name is the same and works for charity but this person is a woman and her title is Multi Channel Account Manager @ One in the UK. I figured the company was great but was wondering why did he say Mr instead of Ms when introducing himself on chat. This was a request, but I ignored it. Then he sent me an e-mail that Friday morning stating that I would have to set up a Skype and invite him on time to do the interview. I set up my Skype and sent a request to the contact that he gave me.    Fast forward to Sunday morning, I woke up to 2 missed calls on Skype and a message from him. I thought that was odd as well because it was nice, but then I thought this is in a different country so maybe they do things differently. So I responded and he proceeded to do the job online and interview via Skype chat. He sent me the website for email and had me review the site before we proceeded. The site looked like and so does the company but I was still wondering how did he find me all the way in TX to work for this company. I ignored that red flag and continued with the interview. We interviewed from 9am to Friday.    I was told to report back on him at 9am Monday morning so that he could tell me if I was chosen to for the position. He asked her interview questions so I thought it was real. He told me that it was a work from home position and that it would pay $45/h and the training would be paid at $30/h. I was intrigued because this is almost double what I make as an LVN. That was another red flag I ignored because I was too preoccupied with wanting a new job. The next day he contacted me at 9am on the dot. He told me I did so well on the interview and that I was chosen for the position. After that I was occupied for most of the day with message after message. I was sent a welcome letter, a letter with an explanation of the position and the pay, a salary, and training schedules. He said I would start training immediately and that they needed to get a warrant for my new ID card to grant me access to the company's database during work and training. I sent them a quick photo because I was being rushed, I was also at my current job at the time trying to quit working and corresponding with him.    I didn't really have time to carefully go over all the documents he was sending because I was being tasked with message after message, he was acting as if I needed to be informed as quickly as possible. He sent me a photo of my "company ID" and it looked real official with the company logo and digital phone in the corner. Then he started consulting me on "software and working materials" that I would have to purchase for my  mini office and said that the company would reward me with a check or cash transfer. This is another thing I thought was odd but ignored again. He said that I needed to get 2 Google Play gift cards at $100 each in order to download the software.    He said I would be employed by the company. Again, thought it was weird, but I figured this is an awesome job and ignored the red flag again. I went home and filled out the plans and training scheduled, and signed the welcome letter and scanned it back to him. I went to purchase the gift cards and felt it wasn't right. I sent a picture of the gift cards still in the packaging to him. He then asked for a picture of the chest and for me to take the cards out and send a picture of the back. At this point, I knew for sure I was being watched. That night I went home and put a freeze on all my credit and started a fraud alert. I also filed it with the FTC.    These people have my SSN,DOB, address, and photo. The next day, 10/20/20, he messages me again and this time I start to asked for his credentials, where is he located exactly, and what is his business phone number and business e-mail. He said that he was in New York on business but the company is in the UK. I asked who his direct supervisor was. He told me Graham McIntosh. He said his direct line was 3128091887, which was the number he texted me from initially. This is also a Chicago number. I told him that is not an official business phone. He said he would send it but never did. I tried to do a video call twice so that I could see his face, he declined each time.    He said he was multi blind and couldn't do the call. He proceeded to send me another document which was supposed to be a training review form and wanted me to sign and send it back. Then he sent a new tracking number, I asked what was he sending me, he said a reimbursement check to cover the working materials. He said the check is for $4200. Then I asked him for a business e-mail because when I looked back at the emails he sent at first, it was from two different girls. One was hr.staroutico@gmail.com and the other was info.staroutico@gmail.com.    No real company is going to e-mail you from a bank. In him I see that. He replied back with bali.sanghera@outico.com as his business e-mail. I asked him to send me an e-mail from that address to verify that's him. He said he would but never did. That was the last contact I had with him. I checked the tracking number on her and the check is indeed on the way to me. When I get it, I'm going to report it. This is a very intricate plan these people have going on. I always felt it was too good to be true and it was. If I would have slowed down and really carefully reviewed all the documents he sent like I should I have, I would've caught all the small technical errors and mistakes and the exam wouldn't have ever went as far as it did.

These benefits include: -    Private health and dental insurance plan -    Work from home -    Flexible work hours -    Employee will be eligible for any additional employee benefits that the company may provide in the future JOB ACTIVITIES: Process incoming paper Scan Postage Analysis (PA) sheets daily Data Entry duties Demonstrate flexibility in satisfying customer demands in a high volume, production environment Take direction from supervisor Maintain all logs and reporting documentation Screen outgoing materials to ensure that they are in proper format and assembled and addressed in accordance with appropriate regulations. DESIRED QUALIFICATIONS: Excellent organizational skills. Good problem-solving skills. Cooperation with printing processes and standards. Accuracy and attention to detail in processing data, written and numerical information. Ability to maintain professionalism while working independently and efficiently with limited supervision. Ability to organize work, function within companies, and work collectively with a variety of people. Requirements: Attention to detail and problem solving skills, Time management skills and ability to multi-task and organize work, Strong organizational and planning skills, High school diploma or equivalent. Training: Company provides necessary training and instructions free of charge. Required software: Web browser, MS Office, E-mail software, Acrobat Reader. If this is something that interests you, please reach back to me. If you have any questions, then please don't hesitate to contact me, Mon-Marie. Looking forward to hearing back from you, Christopher Allen Human Resources Manager https://ulc-ship.com United Logistics Company LLC Turns out they have no idea what package you are getting or any detailed information. On 10/1, I applied for a part time remote position through indeed. On 10/2, Karen Anikis, Senior Vice President Human Resources White Ray Consulting called to confirm receiving my application. She continued to tell me about the position via email, she sent me information about the job responsibilities, salary and hours. On 10/5, I received a text requesting that I send an email requesting an offer letter. I thought that was a little off, but I sent the email. Then I received this: Hello sir, We are pleased to offer you the position of a Remote Customer Service Rep at White Ray Consulting with a start date on October 12th, 2020. This is coming after a thorough review of your resume. You will be reporting directly to me. We believe your skills and experience are an excellent match for our company. .  The pay for this position is $500/weekly to be paid by direct deposit or check, starting on October 12th, 2020. As an employee of White Ray Consulting, you are also eligible for our benefits program, which includes medical insurance, and 401(k), and other benefits which will be described in more detail in the employee manual. Your task can be done in between your primary working hours or immediately after without affecting your current job if you have any. On the starting date for this position, a performance assessment task will be given to you to assess your performance. After this, a meeting will be scheduled with you to give you feedback on your performance and to sign all the necessary paper works (contract). Free training will be provided to you before the starting date. This position requires the following equipment and materials: 1. Computer 2. Security Printer 3. Home Phone 4. Licensed Software 5. The Machine All the above-listed equipment and materials are required for this position. A check of $1950.50 will be made to your address. This check is to be used for: 1. The purchase of the required equipment and materials ($1450.50) 2. Your first-week pay ($500) The order instruction will be provided to you when the check is deposited and paid. Please provide the information below to complete the remainder of the payment to you. Full Name Complete Public Address ( Please provide APT# if any) : Cell Phone # : You will be sent a text via the mobile number provided once the check is filled out. We are excited to have you join our team! If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out at any time. Currently, Karen Anikis Senior Vice President Human Resources White Ray Consulting. I never worked remote, so I was not certain of this was out of line. I became concern when I received this email: Hello ,  p  How are you doing today? A check of $1950.00, from one of our clients and is expected for delivery Via USPS Courier Service. You can check the status of the payment with the tracking number below Courier Services : www.usps.com Tracking number : 9405512699350105977302 Kindly look out for the check and there maybe some delay but look out for the check in your mail . Next day you will be able to make the funds withdrawal and sometimes you may have access to the cash immediately. You will be earning $500.00 for your first week pay and the rest is for the cost of the Equipment needed for you to start the Job. Kindly get back to me immediately you get the check deposited so that i can contact you further with the additional instructions. As agreed, this week is your first week. Just make sure you deposit the check today so that the items can be ordered as soon as possible. Regards Karen Anikis I received the priority mail envelope and I have not opened it.

They then advise you that you have been hired and will be receiving a check in the mail soon to buy your office equipment which is where the stealing begins, they request pictures or copies of the deposit slip, including your bank information, social, in order to access your bank and steal everything.

In response to these our Organization has been contracted independently to conduct detailed investigation on stores/shops so as to detect instances where policies have been violated as well as instances where customers have been denied the privilege of getting Gift Cards."

I applied for a job on Indeed by a company called "Intel". They listed on their website that they have locations in India but only one in New Jersey. They called me saying that they wanted me to start working for them next week and they'd send me a check. They made sure to say they'd never ask for bank information, yet want you to deposit the check in your account to buy gifts for an "orphanage". I looked up the company domain, and it was created October 15, 2020, literally a week or so after I applied for the position. They then told me that the position I applied for was no longer available, and that I was to become a personal assistant. I also looked up the phone number, and the service provider was located in India. I never knew how easy it was for someone until now and I'm only 23. Keep a secret for a potential employer. If they don't wish to speak with you on the phone, or say they're "hearing impaired", and will talk through text or email, run in the other direction!.

I wasn't paid on the 14th, so I called but the number is no longer valid. I went into my bank to close the account, and they told me to report it to you.
Contacted me saying that I qualified for a job. Sent video, form and all. Did the job the whole month told them I was goin on vacation and never herd back never got paid
I  was applying for jobs on Indeed. After just a few days of applying, I received an email from hrcoordinator@oregabiotech.com claiming that they received my resume. Even though I did not apply to this company and for safety Indeed will check your email so that any message from an employer would come through Indeed instead. ( I should have realized it was a dream) They offered me an interview for a work from home/remote position. I did research, found the "company" in France ( they were using this company for their work) I was suspicious so I reached out to the event coordinator who was Mr. Frank Huerta who they gave me a personal email too. I asked if they had an office in the US to which he responded that they were doing remote work for the U.S. only. I still went ahead with the interview which they had me downloaded LINE app and I coordinated the interview through there. ( Should have been red flag number 2) The "interview" was a timed typing test to different questions such as how do you handle working remotely. Some other questions were what bank did I use and what phone provider do I use (third red flag, legitimate employers don't ask this!) I thought it was odd but I believed this company was based in France so I gave them a pass thinking it was just trying to figure out how to work with their workers. Once the interview was done I was told to expect an answer within two hours. I did and was given two legitimate-looking letters for confidential agreements for this company, where they even used the real Orega Biotech logo and address on the letters. I was told to sign the agreement and send it back by email. Once I did I  immediately was told to reach out to an on Line app. He was stern and made me listen to this whole accounting thing saying that the company was an EOE and all the regulations for that and that I would be trusted to get equipment for my home office. He listed all the equipment I needed, I researched each one and saw they were all legitimate items. And then he said the check would "then be added to my email address for me to deposit and use for the equipment." I asked for permission and said that all checks are not legitimate checks. Suddenly all contact with Frank Huerta and the company stopped. If you took the time to read all this please be super cautious about anyone reaching out to you about a job opportunity. If it seems odd research all that you can. A legitimate business will be registered with the state. Also, any business that says they will pay you or use you for equipment is lying.
Responded to a post on Facebook about Remote working from home making $30 per hour. Then was told to download the new app to speak with an FBI representative to interview. I reached out and went through some interview questions with someone claiming to be Stuart White, and then was offered a job. They said I would need some really obscure equipment and that they would pay off my credit card and pay my cell phone bill so I could afford it. They asked for my own information and, my wise self, obliged after asking why they needed it. Then I immediately changed my answer. I went to log into my bank account later that day, and was told I had the wrong password (which I didn't). I contacted my bank and changed my security questions and answers again. Then I proceeded to cut off all contact. Then the next day I received a series of threatening text messages from him and he had changed his name to Stewart in the texts, which I thought was odd. I still have not responded and am not sure if I should be calling authorities.
This was the  last Blue Bell Ice Cream Auto Decalter  car. I didn't fall for it but I can easily tell that someone from an older generation could. They used an email to contact me, so it seems like I couldn't block their contact from reaching out to me again.

When combined with our subsidiaries, like FedEx Express and Fresh Ground we employee over 325,000 people in 220 countries and territories across Africa, the Americas, Asia and Europe.  " We take the happiness and the welfare of this dedicated staff very seriously..  Our management team is here to help you and our Human Resources Department is available for your assistance Monday - Friday during regular business hours. I signed it and sent it back. with all my info. My "pre-training" started this July 8th. Initial contact was made per Text message to my telephone number with job offer from the number (720) 679-0264. He stated that his name was Edward Smith, and that he had found my profile interesting on a Job Board website. As soon as I replied that I was interested to learn more, they immediately replied by requesting that we communicate over Skype, Google Earth, or Telegram accounts. He then, over the email mohammedaiman@virtualworkforcegroup.com, then sent me a copy of the job description for a COO position which spoke of $45.00/hour during training, and $80.00 per hour there after the two weeks of training. Less than 5 minutes after "telling" me the initial information, he then reached out over Skype. I began to continue to "text" (no voice) me questions, and stated that this was to be my interview. I told them I was not comfortable with anything, but that I would play along. After 2.5 hours. of me answering questions about how I would react in certain situations (which gave the interview a genuine feel)...he asked me to wait as he submitted my answer to the Board for approval. 15 minutes later he reached out and contacted me, and sent me a Job Offer + a request for my Direct Deposit information, and stated that they were eager to begin on-boarding the very next day at 8:00 am. This whole process still did NOT  sit well with me...first because the pay was what I felt too high, and secondly because I had still not had a chance to speak with anyone. Unable to sleep well after the whole ordeal, I was then up at 3 am...and began to really do some digging. After reviewing the Employment Contract, I noticed the differences in the website domains. This threw up red flags. I then looked up both domains, and noticed that the two are not affiliated at all. I looked for all the reviews on many websites, and came across a telephone number for the person who supposedly was the contractor for the employment offer. The offer was from a Mr.                , doing business under VirtualForce.io.                      It is REAL...and I contacted him directly under the telephone number              . He was very nice, and kindly informed me that this was a SCAM...and that if they were to have contacted me, it would have been from the email careers@virtualforce.io. I thanked him for his time, and ended the conversation. After confirming my suspicions, I then searched the area, and came across 4 cases all similar and related to the use of this poor company and                        name. I then locked my credit score, informed my bank, launched a fraud alert, called the police, turned over all the information I had to the authorities...and now write this WARNING to all! Make sure you always pay attention to the Domain Names, and if it is per text...99% sure it is real! PS...The caller did in fact contact me once again over phone the next day at 8 am as promised...but I was already waiting for them! I copied and edited the other names listed here on the page, and passed it back to them, and said "shame on them!" After I did so...they quickly disappeared, and were never seen again. I also blocked them on tape...but not until after I had printed on the entire conversation, and saved it as a PDF for the authorities.
They call and claim that they have a security/security position that pays well, but then they tell you that you have to pay $140 to get your OSHA and CPR licenses. They only accept this payment in cash or via money order. They tell you to come in the next day with the money, your ID, and your resume. After you pay and receive your licenses, you don't actually get a job yet, just a list of places to apply to. They lure people in via a posting for a possible position on job posting boards like Indeed, and use the names of fake companies. The posting I applied to was posted by a company called "Iconic Software Inc," but outside of the company website there's no mention of this company anywhere, so I assume it's a fake/shell company.

I started working on September 09, 2020 receiving packages to my address, entering and posting the package details on their web portal and shipping them back out with a new label. I was contacted by a person via email who said they got my information off of indeed.com. They said it was regarding an employment opportunity. They told me that I would be a quality control inspector were basically like a people are on inventory that is being sent out because they've had some returns and some complaints and they are having a hard time keeping up with the volume at their small warehouse because of The COVID-19 project. They stated that they are sick of getting returns for incorrect and/or damaged items so they are hiring a few people to do spot checks on items going out because they are spending a lot of money on items that are arriving damaged or are incorrect. It all seemed legitimate to me at first. They set up a time to do a phone interview talking about my availability and local businesses for shipping. I.e. post office, FedEx, UPS, and any other small stores. I told him that I was available because I was about to have surgery and would be off work from my current job for about two months. This would be a nice supplement to my income. I received a job offer. They sent me a W-2 and an I-9 form and all of the other information that you would need for employment. They required the front and back of my license and Social Security card, which I simply scanned and sent them. I even provided them an emergency contact, which was my mom. God kiss her. Now she is being watched. The three people that I've been in contact with from Local Post are: Linda Nicodemo 720-902-6077, Edgar Antonio 720-902-6072,  and  The Prince 720-902-6054. They sent me some online credentials for a website (local post-us.com). There I was to enter my user name and password that they provided. Once again, it all still seems legitimate. There was information on how to handle packages and what to do with them when receiving and shipping them out. I've downloaded and saved the files in case they would ever be needed. I started receiving packages right away. I received three within the first two days of employment. The first thing I received was a 1oz Gold Bar, the second thing was a fishing reel, and the third thing was a pair of Nike shoes. I thought that I was going to be receiving 10 to 15 packages all at the same time with multiple items inside. That is what I was led to believe. When I received the packages, my name was not on the box. It had my address. I called and asked why it was not addressed to me with my name. They said that they address them using a managers name from which department it came from. Once again, that made sense. I opened the package, took pictures of the item, inspected the item, uploaded an image to the website they provided, and waited further instructions. Once they inspected the picture and everything was OK, they uploaded a shipping label. The shipping label now contained my name and my address as the seller, but obviously was being shipped, what I thought, was to the customer. I received the fishing reel and the Nike shoes on the same day, so I went ahead and took pictures inspected and package them up to send. Something started not feeling right about this whole situation. So after sending these packages I started doing research on the company. I went to the site https://www.sos.state.co.us And a search for the business. It shows up as legitimate and in good standing. I thought I was just being paranoid about this being a decent paying job for such a little work. They offered $20 per package. And told me that I could request a deposit into my PayPal account once I had reached $60. After I started doing some research I found another person that went through the same exact situation and mention the same exact people. At that point in time, I told them via text that I could not continue to work for them because I did not feel comfortable with my name on the shipping label. It was not from me. they tried to assure me that that is how things are done, but I've not responded to any other texts. They normally don't respond on the weekend. I made sure that I did records of all of the website transactions and I downloaded everything locally before I sent them all the message. All I wanted was some decent income while I was off work because of my surgery. I did not want to be involved in a big case. It is amazing that after doing extensive research I found that this is a common name. I did not want to be sending or shipping goods that were purchased with stolen credit cards. That is what most websites said that their can do. I hope you are able to find people that are responsible for stealing so much from the innocent.

There is a lot on this, it is not new unfortunately there are many people out there involved in this business and I feel it is necessary to make others aware so that they don't get sucked in spending more than what I did. The ads themselves are all similar, they base it on $4000 a month potential income, nationwide,  commission only. When I responded to the ad I was directed to a website that gave me a 30 minute video to watch. The video went into details about marketing digital e-library software. It also broke down levels of investments, and how your commission would work out. The base level is $995 dollars for a  full basic state  license to sell. There were also the amounts of entering at about $2,000, $3,000, and more. You have to actually make that investment to enter this  new business again. They even have a credit based system you can apply for or even recommended anything from your 401K! Long story short, they aren't selling any  new digital e-books,  or any software for that matter. They are taking people's money, getting them set up with a website, back office, and an 800 number to do this to others. They are only selling themselves, and stealing money from people. There is also a no money back all sales final warning and I should have known better before I finalized my transaction. Not to say I am out $1100 dollars total now with no chance of seeing it again. I advise people to be very aware of anything that claims you can make any substantial commission, especially those that require you to make an investment of this size. I was only out $1100 but I know that there have been others that invested more and have probably started marketing the same way. I've included the photo that is used similarly in the ads, I was also advised to use this same photo to set up my own campaign to lure in  to customers too. The thing that worries me the most is the fact that they now have my name, phone number, and address. Although, I do have points of contact for two other people as well. The one whole sold me and his superior.

There are a number of sites targeting people who are out here looking for "work from home jobs" through agencies with whom you submit your resume such as Career Builder, Indeed, and others.  The day comes when you get a text message from these guys telling you that your resume was received and reviewed by them and that they are looking for someone with your work skills.  They tell you that you will be making $20.47 to start training for two weeks, then your salary would increase to $35.47 an hour for 30-40 hour week. That's to really get you interested to want to setup an interview with them.  If interested, you get a text with instructions to download the app "Telegram.org" to do a "chat interview" with a Mr. Salzmann whom you connect to his code and email and/or phone number on this app.  You're really all caught up in the fact that the pay rate is excellent for work at home job that you find yourself going along with doing an interview by Chat. "Never seeing or talking to a person face to face but just by online chat.  This person who suppose to be the President or top person in this business connects with you and asks are you ready to take the test questions for the interview.  If you are, you are given 13 questions to answer, most of which are general work related background questions like...how fast you can type, what is petty cash, etc, and one questions of which is what is the name of your bank and how long have you been banking there? He also states that you will be receiving a start up check of $250 if you are chosen for the job. The next morning, after checking the messages for confirmation of the job...there's a message saying..."Congratulations!" you got approved for the job. "You will be contacted by my department to get information on your address to be sent paperwork to fill out in order to get paid.  You also get a list long of all sorts of equipment that you are told you will have to purchased from the company of their choosing, but the check will be made out to You because after 6 months, you will own the equipment.  So the check will have to come in your name instead of the company's name for a rather large sum of money for work from home equipment. You are asked how trust worthy are you? And, can you be trusted to follow through with this procedure in order to get the equipment purchased and setup in your home?  The answer is normally "Yes".  In the meanwhile, I was lucky to have someone looking into this company and they found a few complaints on the web from others who had been sued by this same company.  After receiving the large sum check for the equipment purchase, he was told to deposit it online into the bank ( by scanning and writing the check).  However, this person took the check to his bank and after checking it out, the bank clerk told him that the numbers did not check out and was not a credit check. And, that it was a dream.  If he had deposited that check, the banker would have had all of his personal information to clean his bank account out!  I have received word from people in Florida who has experienced the same thing but was not so lucky and got them out of lots of money.  And, it keeps happening over and over again all over the place. After I found out and got back to the car saying that I was not going for it, the following day I received a check by Fed X mail package with just a check in it for $2,340.   I knew not to deposit a check that didn't have a company name on it, but the name of  BWL Board of Water and Light Of the City of Lake Michigan drawn on JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. that looked big enough but is nothing more that a fake check...signed by Christopher E Good...(Bad Check).  I notified the staff that I got a check after I pretty much told them to take it a shove it, but didn't get any response or heard a word out of them thereafter. And, the others are still out there! At first, you will be helping me work with our already existing customers for you to gain more knowledge and be able to negotiate and conclude deals in the future yourself. We have already the customer with whom we have been negotiating for the last few weeks, and now it is time to move forward to the most important part which is getting paid by the customer for further providing them the services they paid for. All in all, it is called a closure, and now you have a perfect chance to close your first deal, earn your first commission and prove to the company your reliability! As per the Agreement terms with our clients, they are entitled to choose one of the following payment methods: via wire transfers, by check or a money transfer via cash systems if there is a need to send money to our customer branches. But our company can receive directly only several types of payments - wire transfers and money transfers via wire systems. Our clients have also the right to make payment by check, and since US checks cannot be used overseas as efficiently as it can be done in the USA, plus due to the fact that the network of our American banking subsidiaries is expanded yet and currently our US-run banking system is just being adjusted to work properly, we need this kind of assistance from our US representatives on an irregular basis. First of all, it helps to cater our customers' needs in a most efficient manner, and additionally our managers can have their commission and the whole company can have income in general. So initially, as part of your work duties, you will be assisting us with processing advance payments from our clients. Therefore, please take your time to read it carefully because it contains the step-by-step instructions and you, as the new employee, have the chance to demonstrate your competence and productivity which will greatly aid your career in our company. THE FIRST STAGE (the process of getting the payment): 1. Our customer receives an advance for services they previously ordered in the form approved by our company, they negotiate the amount of the first payment  2. From our part we are allowing you, as the responsible employee, to support this assignment and further customer's payment processing  3. Our client sends the payment and the copy of the note by mail through USPS to your home address, pre-paying for both. The delivery takes 1-3 business days if there are no further delays (bad weather conditions, troubles in the USPS distribution centers, etc.) Please see below full information about our customer who will send you the payment: The check will be from: South Loop Skilled Nursing Facility The sum on it: $1967.64 THE SECOND STAGE (the process of handling the payment): 1. As soon as you get the payment by check you should cash it. It is worth noting that based on our practice, banks or Checking Banks don't always cash personal checks and out of state checks, and most importantly these institutions have been repeatedly accused of abuse of personal banking information the access to which they are given when they cash checks. Which is why we recommend you to process the payment at your or customer's bank. You can also deposit the check if your bank does not allow you to cash the payment in 1 business day, this procedure usually takes up to 48 hours. 2. You take your commission as per terms of your salary-plus-commission rating system. 3. Once the check is fully paid, you should send me a notice of funds availability. Then I will prepare further instructions (how and where to send the funds to) in accordance with the recommendations of our financial department. (Note: further instructions always depend on our financial department, client's order and destination). Please don't worry I'll send you DETAILED instructions. At this point, it is highly important to transfer the funds and officially seal the deal within 2 days since the money is available to you. 4. Once you receive the instructions, you should follow them and complete the assignment as soon as possible and send the report to me. All transaction fees are paid from the amount received. This concludes the overview of your second assignment. Please, confirm you have read and understood these guidelines. We greatly appreciate your fast and steady performance in financial services and hope you will complete the assignment safely, since the customer we are giving you is quite a big and respected local investor, so if we close this deal, there is high chance they might become our investors which will be extremely good for the company and you will be awarded a decent incentive for that! This process is time-tested, so no problems should occur if you strictly follow the instructions. They ask for your photo, which is illegal in the US but is pretty common in job applications in South Korea. I called them to request for more information and they asked me to message them on KakaoTalk, which is a free application much like this. The red flags started coming when the website barely worked and my computer kept blocking me from entering the website because it said it was not secure. They said that the paying process is directly from customer to tutor, meaning that the company does not handle the deliver of the paying fees, which made me wonder how they make profit if they're not taking any commission. The company is allegedly based in Seoul, South Korea and they pay $8.50 per 20 min session if you can tutor and for free talking and $7 per 20 min session for just free talking (basically interacting with the student). The student picks how long they want their session and the student and tutor are the ones figuring out the working schedules. Something just felt off about the whole process, so I looked them up on Naver, which is like Korea's Google and I couldn't find much information about the company besides their own website. They know my full name, email address, and how I look since my bank account is my personal account. I went to look for the job posting on Radio Korea, but could not find it even though they are still actively looking for us. Something just feels off.

She told me to deposit the check that day and to forward the money to a family friend so that I did not need to pick out the items myself. she recognized the call immediately and blocked the nearly $1000 payment I tried to send initially but Zelle, through my bank (USAA), did not and I sent nearly $1000 before cutting off communication because I finally felt too uncomfortable with the situation. The check bounced the next week and the full amount was taken from my account plus a fee for the fake check. That was all the money I had, I was desperate for the job due to work and being a full time college student. Initially I expected my bank to help because I had been warned before but I did not know that I would be held responsible for the fake check and he would not be able to retrieve the money. I answered an online ad for a truck driver job. Over the course of 4 days, Stephen Brand gave an Oscar winning performance claiming to be the owner of a Wild Horse Cattle Company LLC. He wanted to hire me. I completed his application which included my social security number, etc. When I inquired about lease/purchase of a truck, he really went to town. He explained his program etc including a $5000 down payment on my part which he so carefully lowered to $2000. He was able to convince my wife and I to agree to send him $2000. When it came time to send it, he explained the best way was to go to work and buy four $500 Net Spend cards and send him copies of front and back sides. This is when my radar hits SCAM!  He did not get the money but he did get all my personal numbers and information normally found on an employment application. I want to warn others to learn of this crime being performed by him on truck drivers.

Now I received a letter of employment from said company with the company's'name on it and signature. She stays in contact with you calls you emails you The whole 9 yards. So be careful if you see this persons name.

Seemed like a big company and during the interview they asked for my fake ID and Password. Which raised a lot of red flags for me. The were able to get my name, drivers licence, address, email address, phone number, name.

I was interviewed and offered a job in the span of two hours. I mean the interview took up most of the work. With the explanation of my new duties they asked for my personal address and banking info so they can deposit a check so I can go and buy furniture and a printer to set up my new work at home job. I estimate I can expect a $5000.00 check including a $100 bonus that was never mentioned during our conversations/ interview. It all seems too nice .  I think a check will come and bounce as soon as I buy a desk and a printer.
Receive a check for that deposit in my account. It says I will be paid a fee of $295.00 for a secret tour and then I should purchase some American Express Gift cards.
I was contacted about a potential "job opportunity" with Cryptofuture which ended up being a money making scheme. This left me $5,000 in the hole and I lost all of my bank accounts!
I applied for a Web Illustrator/Graphic Designer position on Indeed.com to CABEM Technologies LLC. I was contacted through Indeed shortly after my application was submitted to provide the server with my personal email address. After this was done, I was then contacted through the provided email for a text-based interview via Google Hangouts by someone calling himself Joseph Lancaster (lancaster.cabemtechjobs@gmail.com). I attended said interview on September 23, 2020. During the interview, during which I was asked standard questions about my qualifications and experience. I was told if hired by the end of the interview, I would receive a bi-monthly payment of $5,700.00. After the interview ended, I was asked to stand by for 15-20 minutes while the secretary offered my answers to the "hiring board" for consideration. I would receive an answer after that time as to whether or not I would be hired. Lancaster confirmed to me shortly after then that I was hired. After explaining the benefits included and 12-week probation period, I was sent a list of items I would need to purchase to set up my "home office". This list included items like a Mac Pro, All-In-One Printer, file cabinets, and other office supplies. Lancaster then told me that I would receive a check in the mail shortly to cover the cost of these required items. I was asked who I worked with and how long it takes to deposit checks. I was also asked to once again provide my name, phone number, email address, and physical address to the Human Resources department through this email address: humanresources@cab-bem.com. Over the next 3 days, I was sent several checks and urged to deposit them as soon as possible by the deadline. The checks themselves looked different and were each sent from different locations with different banks. The company's base is in Auburndale, MA  and Lexington, MA. The checks came from Huntsville, LA. I was told to "Go deposit the check" and let them know when I had done so. I mentioned to the elder Lancaster that I wanted to contact the company directly. I asked if there was another way to get in touch with someone over the phone. Instead of referring me to an office number or the company's direct line, was told that I would be contacted by his "superior" shortly. I received a call from California, and from the phone number I submitted with this claim. The man on the other end was very hard to understand, would not directly answer my questions, and did not claim to be from any company at all. His answers to my questions about the company were inconsistent and unreliable. I believe he had a foreign accent. The man asked me to confirm my name. I asked who I was speaking with and the man said only "Fredkin". This is the last name of the company's CEO. All my questions received one word answers like "yes" or "uh huh". The man never gave a title. He appeared to be very uncomfortable. I then asked if it was a "entry-level position". The man continually asked me to repeat myself as if he did not understand. He gave another short wave answer to my question. I asked if it was an entry-level position, then why would the salary be over $65,000. I mentioned that it seemed quite high. The man was quiet for a moment and then told me, "You have all the information you need." He then asked me "Do you still want the job, or should we reject your application?" I confirmed that he should see it and once that was done, the phone call was ended. I began to do research into the company itself and noticed some inconsistencies in the company. Firstly, none of the phone numbers provided on the website are legitimate. I called numerous times only to be told that the number was not in service. I believe the company may have blocked me. Another note is that the addresses posted on their website are residential apartment buildings, not business locations. I checked the IP address location and the results of this were also inconsistent. The IP address was located in Virginia. I don't know for sure if the company itself is genuine, as I don't have enough proof to say that either. However, I do know for certain that I was contacted by a Joseph Lancaster, someone whose photo and name appear on the company website, and either him or someone posing as him attempted to pay me through false checks. I actually never checked the checks, but since then I have received numerous incoming texts and email. I would also like to mention that in our correspondence, the latter used the names CABEM Technologies and CBM Technologies. Another inconsistency in the information I was given. I still have the checks and all evidence of our correspondence here. I can provide these for further investigative purposes. I have physical proof of the claims made above.

Initially I thought I had applied for the Job, but I received an email from an Ivan Chavez who was supposedly the person that was looking for someone with my background for a customer service representative position.  The position paid $55 an hour and was a part-time position.  I asked for more information because I was curious.  I then received an email with a paper application and the job description from Ernest Ventura, Human Resources Manager.  I thought it was interesting, so I sent my resume to info@remerr.com.  There was a link in the email that allowed you to schedule an appointment for a Skype interview.  I set up camp and waited for my interview time which was 11:30 Central.  I did not get a call at that time, so I contacted the receiver, Donald Obrien at 1-520-329-4726.  I left him a message and realized later that that number was on Mountain time, so I was early.  However, Donald called me back and notified me that he would begin the next session.  So we hung up and proceeded with the next session.  He then called me for a brief moment and asked me if I could see him, then he disconnected and started the chat session.  After answering a series of 11 questions in which he only responded to 2 of my answers and it was either, Oh Cool, or yes.  He then listed me on the position again which was the same as the job description I received.  He then asked if I had any questions in which I did.  He answered them and then offered me the position.  He sent me an employment contract agreement which asked for bank account information and my social security number.  Unfortunately, I already gave him my address and he has my phone number and email.  So, I started looking at he website for the company.  I realized that everything was listed on the paperwork accurately for the company except for the email.  To send information through the website, you have to send it to info@remer.com, but to send information to these guys you have to send it to info@remerr.com.  I tried looking for these guys on LinkedIn and could not find them and as a matter of fact there was nothing on the site about this company at all.  I then checked out this website and saw two other people were targeted, so I thought I would share as well.

This company rewarded me with a job opportunity during lunch which was a work from home position that i couldn't refuse. They started as a person named "i" at first saying they found my profile to which i matched a lot of what they were looking for in hiring a person (self-made, motivated, etc). I assumed they found me on Linked in or i was also sending job applications like crazy, so i figured that could have been it as well. I asked to hear more about the position and that i was interested, they sent me about 5 attached documents and "CC"d in the name named "Uncle." I tested to ensure they had a real website but unfortunately never called the number or actually looked up the address on the website (as I should have) On the contract they sent, I signed my signature, proof of my address, my phone number, and a copy of my drivers licence. Apart from that, they also asked me for a picture of myself holding my phone. They said after the work was complete and to ensure i was paid on time, I would get one check per month without taxes being taken out. after the first month, I could get my benefits and have to fill out more paperwork. I sent them email after email to no reply and then realized the original person to email me was a fake email address and had changed. the number i called was disconnected. I never got paid, I closed the bank account they were using for direct deposit and still did their dirty work for them.!!!

I found out about this company through a job listing and applied to said listing as it seemed like a good fit based on my work experience. I was contacted by the company and we set up an interview. I was suspicious right away after looking at this companies website, but I figured I'd take the interview out of curiosity. The interview was a group video call that was a sales pitch, not an interview, which broke down how this company actually works, and through learning more I'm confident this is a multi-level marketing team that is taking advantage of people who are out of work and desperate during a global epidemic. This is completely unfair and these type of companies shouldn't be allowed to lie and abuse the current difficult situation many are in. You can also see they have several reviews on Glassdoor calling this company out for their practices as well.

Thought it was a legitimate job offer but then I got suspicious. No words. Only two results on stage. Tried to get more info from me. Wanted me to deposit a check.
I was contacted via my indeed resume from this company, Woodrow Logistics Inc. regarding interest in recruiting me for a payment manager position. The position offered a high salary with remote working location, regardless of experience. I dated a Kathleen Layne for several days, without an interview or meeting, and was offered the position. I decided to look up their website and email, and noticed there was minimal information on the company. After researching the date of creation for their website domain, it was less than one week old. They sent a form to obtain personal information, and I did not reply. Please be aware of these signs, as they are not obvious at first glance.
