I sent an inquiry to Ford Models on Saturday looking to start getting into plus size modeling. This company was looking for brand ambassador and also included help with a portfolio and modeling jobs. Someone from this page asked me after I sent the inquiry with a selection a clothes to pick from to begin things. I was told the clothes were free and that all I had to pay was a shipping and handling fee of $12.95. After paying, I was then told it would take 2-3 business days for the clothing to arrive and that I would receive an email from a representative with information regarding a portfolio and photo shoots. I was recently contacted via text message by someone using the phone number (609) 697-2566. This person claimed to be one Mr. Alan F Herbert representing Blossom Spring Publishing, a company based in the United Kingdom. They claimed that Blossom Spring Publishing was looking to open offices in the United States and thus needed to fill a great many positions. They claimed that they had received my resume from Indeed and would like to interview me for an editorial position in their company. I had recently applied for several such positions on Indeed but did not remember Blossom Spring Publishing being one of them. I checked my account and found that I had not applied to the company. This raised my suspicions, so I contacted Indeed to confirm if it was possible that they might have shared my resume with companies I hadn't specifically applied to if they were searching for candidates to fill positions similar to those that I had applied to. I decided to cautiously treat the person claiming to be Mr. Herbert as though they were legitimate until I had proof otherwise but would not share any information with them that was not included on my resume. I scheduled an interview for later that evening and was surprised and again suspicious by the revelation that the interview was to be conducted via the app Telegram Messenger. I went along with the interview, remaining careful not to reveal any information which was not listed on my actual resume. After completing the interview I was almost immediately presented with a job offer. Which, again, deepened my suspicion. I was sent an email from the address career@blossomspringspublishing.com. This too was suspicious, as the website for Blossom Spring Publishing is blossomspringpublishing.com, not blossomspringspublishing.com. The email contained a PDF document of an offer letter. The letter itself contained a number of technical errors and confusion. I asked about them but was not given an answer. reached out to Blossom Spring Publishing via both the company website and the company Facebook page to explain that I had been offered a position with the company that I found suspicious and to confirm as to the legitimacy of  the Alan Herbert,  as a representative of the company. As of the time of writing, I have yet to receive a response. The next day, I was sent an email containing a PDF file of a check for $2,300 made out to one Kelly Sheree       along with instructions that I was to print the check out and deposit it into my bank account via a mobile banking app. I did not do this. I was contacted again via Telegram Messenger with instructions that I was to purchase a number of software licenses to install on a Mac Pro that was going to be shipped to my address and that my purchases would be reported in full. I did not do this. I inquired as to why it was necessary for me to purchase licenses at all, arguing that certainly the company could purchase the licenses and then provide me with the download key upon the arrival of the supposed license. I was told that it was standard business practice to have new owners purchase their own licenses. At about that time, I was contacted by a representative of Indeed relating to my inquiry from the previous day. I was told that Indeed had no knowledge or record of the company Blossom Spring Publishing and that my resume had not been shared with any entities aside from those to which I myself had applied.

I was registered on Glassdoor and have been involved with many companies. Pepsico had a job on Glassdoor. I received an email saying I was selected to apply for a remote job with them. They wanted me to answer 21 questions in Word Doc about how I work, which is standard lately. Then they wanted a Skype text interview. Still pretty standard. They offered me the job and said they would be sending me a mini office to use. Still standard. 1 previous company I worked for did this and my sister's company did this for her. The red flag was they were going to send me a check to cover the cost of the equipment (over $10,000) and I was to purchase it from THEIR vendor. Some some job ads and found this was a 'thing' in Canada in 2018. They would send you a real looking (but fake) check for over the amount and then ask you to send them a check for the price. Their check goes, you're out over $10,000. I ended this before I lost any money. Thank you too.

I received a check for 3,750 to use their company on my car.
I was contacted by this company through email, they said they found my resume on Indeed.com and thought I'd be a good fit. The benefits seemed really good, and the pay was $38.40 per hour, full time, which is extremely big. I was "hired" by this company as a "Payment Manager", with literally no interview. I connected with a woman named Lisa Milton via email, then through a messenger app called Telegram. They said I would be working remotely. On the first day, they gave me instructions on the tasks I needed to complete, as follows: "You will receive funds from the accounting department through Zelle. As soon as you receive the funds, you need to inform me about it. After that, you need to get to an ATM or bank branch to cash out 95% of the total amount. 5% is your reward. As soon as you withdraw funds from the bank you should inform me about it. Because I have to send a confirmation to the accounting department that you have withdrawn funds. After that, you need to get to the ETH (BT) ATM and deposit cash into the ETH (BT) ATM.(I will give you the address of the nearest ETH, later) Please let me know if you are ready to process the payment." (ETH stands for Ethereum, and BTC stands for Bitcoin) I immediately knew that no business would ask their employees to use their personal accounts to transfer money. Red flag! When I looked into the company and tried to contact them with the phone numbers on their website, the numbers were disconnected. When I asked "Kim" about the disconnected phone numbers, she gave me some clues about how the operators have "disabled incoming calls". The hourly pay of $38.40/hour was very low, so I could see how someone could fall into this trap, thinking it's some kind of big break.

Promised Project Manager work from home job with 5 weeks of paid training, 4 weeks online, 1 in New York. Took 4 weeks of tests online for agreed paid training. Open book, so tests were easy. Offered mini-project, during training for extra money--which was the same, to buy 6 of X, using their Purchase Order (PO). PO was supposed to deposit to my account but never does. Michael Atwood, lead actor, never returns phone calls, only e-mail. 1st red flag. Angela Adams was the original contact, who disappears after first introducing the team. 2nd red flag. I couldn't find any of my e-mail with her or open the Transpoint Shipping Lines website. Then a week later, Michael Atwood contacts me, posing as the lead man, who will be my training lead. Website page. I ask Michael about Angela and why he never answers his phone. No answer. 3rd red flag. He sends the weekly training materials and tests. After week 2, he asks if I'd like to make extra money doing a mini-project, which was to buy  and  send 6 in X to a customer in Hong Kong. 4th red flag, because there are Apple stores in Hong Kong, per the Apple store. Michael sends all info on how to request the PO funds, using their instructions, all by looking with diagram examples of Chase and Wells Fargo bank. The account's routing number is a Wells Fargo account, according to one of my banks. In anticipation of the PO funds, I bought the 6 phones with my credit card but held them, waiting for the PO funds to arrive in my bank account, which never did. 5th red flag. After a week of waiting for the funds and not getting any good news from Michael about them, I personally went to my 2 banks, to see if the problem was on my end. Two of my bank records told me it sounded like a trap, but I knew I had the phones and could return them, hoping it was not a trap. 6th red flag. I even e-mail Michael after the bank visits, and he assured me that the money was canceled when I inquired at the bank because the account is highly sensitive. That I need to wait for the PO funds. 7th red flag. By this time, I'm        up and e-mail Michael, since he doesn't answer the phone or call back, asking if it was a joke, telling him I was going to report him to the FBI. Michael's classic response: "Is this a joke? I don't get it." 8th red flag. After the 4th week of testing, the next week would have been when they paid to send me to New York. I kept asking about the PO funds and Michael said he'd check with Zurich HQ (which is where the fake ID was). After almost 2 weeks of waiting for the PO funds, I returned the phones and called and e-mail Michael.. Once he knew I returned phones, he stopped contact with me. The 9th red flag. The website has been taken down. I kept all e-mail and calls, which LOOK. BUT IT'S FAKE. The individual went through a lot to create (or steal) training materials, put up a legitimate-looking website, and carry on the work for weeks. Huge waste of time and disappointment. Lesson: if it sounds too good to be true, it most likely is. Stop after the 1st red flag.

I originally applied for a job as a quality inspector on job-Line. I was contacted via email from this company describing the job and to let them know if I was interested. I did reply back that I was interested and what they needed from me. Eventually I was sent a contract I needed to read and sign. Plus they said they needed a picture of me with my driver's license along with high-end pictures of the document I signed. I continued with all of this, seeing no reason not to. I was "hired" and given an employee account to monitor all company information and the packages I would receive. I was urged to give in my bank account number along with my routing number for direct deposit. I was also introduced to a person who was supposed to me my manager via a message system within my employee account. He sent me a message detailing what I was to do when I received a package. It took a long time to receive my first package weeks from when I was officially hired. When my first package showed up in my store the instructions gave me the name the package it would be addressed to, the weight, and a description of the item. Also there was a place for a tracking number but for this item it was blank. That first package arrival date came and went with no package and no contact. I contacted my hiring manager and asked him what was going on and he said he had no way of knowing. Anyway people say I never received that original package even though it stayed on my package list for a couple weeks. Moving on, it took a while before I got another indication that a package would be coming with all the same information and this one actually showed up a day before what was specified. I did as I was instructed  took pictures of the contents and the packing slip and uploaded them to my account. This item was actually a coach purse and the box itself had the coach logo inside, so it seemed legitimate. My name was nowhere on the package, just my address with a different name. Also the name the item was addressed to different than the a name I ultimately named the item to. After this, I was told that there was a decreased number of packages compared to previous times. As a result of this they said that regardless of the packages received you would be paid a base salary of $1,120 a month. Previously my pay was based solely on how many packages you inspected and shipped off. But would get the base along with an extra $30 for every package inspected and shipped. I had no idea what is was because it did not show up on my desk. I contacted my manager and he gave me no information about it. Then I received another package that was in my purse. Both this of packages were addresses to the same name, Noah Wilson. But I could only process the one that was in my packages. Then I received another package that was not in my purse and I tried to log on to my account and wasn't able to. I thought it was just a temporary thing and I tried later and the next day but it did not change. I tried their website and tried the only email I had from previous use during the hiring process. I never heard anything and during this time I was supposed to me paid which never happened. After hearing nothing for weeks I figured I was screwed and there was nothing I could do. I still have those two items. I never got any information on those.

I was looking for a job, so I posted my resume and applied for many positions with indeed.com.   I received an email from a Gary along with An ENERGY RECRUITMENT.   He said that he is with the PALADIN ENERGY HR department in the U.S.  I was scheduled for an interview and it went very well and I was offered the position.  I went through the first week of training using the software, Telegram, and his account is @darrenmooreHR.  He had me doing different tasks, from doing financial research on different companies to writing articles on different business practices.  I thought nothing of it.  I figured it was to prepare me for the analyzing and critically thinking of business practices and financial statements that I will be dealing with the position.  I had online positions before and the training is not so much different, it's just on a different field.  Come the second week of training, he sent me a check that was to cover the cost of equipment that I will need to do my job, laptop, printer, desk, filling cabinet, etc.  And he wanted me to get my pay from that check.  I was very suspicious at this point.  Usually the company will order such equipment and ship it to an employee, especially a worldwide company like PALADIN ENERGY LTD.  Also I had asked him to direct deposit my compensation into my bank account, and it's quite odd that he never asked for my direct deposit routing number (It's a good thing that I never gave it to him also).  He, Darren Moore, handed me a tracking number with me with regards to the check that he had sent me to cover all of the expenses.  And another thing that is odd is that the delivery status of the package is on pending for almost a week.  According to FBI, the package is listed as being sent from Dearborn, MI.  But further inspection after waiting for three days, it was actually being picked up from Costa Mesa, CA.  At this point, I started to ask him about this business practice of sending me a check, and for me to use this fund which will be coming out of my personal account to buy the equipment.  Why would a vendor prefer to accept a personal credit card over multi-national's company's credit card.  His answer was that in the past, employees claimed to have not received the equipment, so the vendor now only accept payments from the employee.  After a few days had passed, still the status of the package is still pending.  Dad wanted me to use my own money or credit card to buy the equipment, which I'd said no to.    I kept asking him about this unusual business and to have him ask  me ENERGY to buy the equipment. The communication got less frequent to the point where he didn't correspond with me on Telegram today.  So I told him that he is a con artist I am going to report him and I ENERGY it to the FBI, so here I am.  I also sent an email to PALADIN ENERGY, which is a company based out of Australia, with all the details of the interactions that Darren Moore and I had, emails and chat history.

Back in July 2020, I was putting out many applications on Indeed, and though this was one of the people I was waiting to hear back from. I received an email, and thought really nothing of it. I called back, a phone interview was scheduled, waited to hear back in three days if I got the job, and I got it. They told me what I'd be doing. I would be on a rotating basis the first month. At the end of the month they stated an examination would occur to see if I was eligible for a full time position. They sent me information for my supervisor, and myself, which I had to fill out a W-2 tax form, and I also gave them pictures of my License and Social security card, and a year long contract was signed. They stated a one payment check would be sent to me for the amount of $2,700 on the 26th of August for working Monday-Friday days. Only full employees held on after the contract period could receive direct deposits. (Also, I'd be paid for gas and materials used for work such as a printer, phone, camera, printer paper, ink, packing materials, and time spent working after hours.) What my job required of me is receiving packages, checking the packages for damaged content, taking pictures to pose for the customers, dealing with materials I bought, printing out a new packing list and shipping label sent to me through their employee website called (Echo-crm.net), and sending them to ER/UPS...I would then draw pictures of the device and new tracking number. The items I received varied from a side table, a wine glass, Victoria secret panties, electronics suck as apple/mac products, and food items. I kept in touch with my supervisor who was super friendly and helpful throughout this whole process. I didn't suspect a thing until the end of the month of August when he called me saying the vacation time was ended, and they would take 7-10 business days to hear back from me. I got a weird urge to confirm I would still have the one year contract as a part time employee, which they kind of hinted at when they first hired me. Their reply said if I didn't get the full time position, I would not be working at their company. Confused, I started to search for job opportunities just in case I didn't get the position, but I was so sure I would because I did everything by the book and held great communication with my supervisor. I waited 2-3 days past the initial 7-10 business days and still no reply. My check also didn't appear in the mail. Worried, I contacted her and asked to speak with her over the phone instead of email like I usually did, but replied that she might have time later that day and asked what I wanted to speak about. I told them there was a problem with my phone and I wanted to know the status of my decision of full time employment. He told me there was a delay in gathering a conclusion, and they were sorry, and to contact you. She gave me the phone number, which I called during business hours. It just went to hell. So I left a message and called them. I didn't hear back from them for almost a day and a half. I called her and told them my problem, and how worried I was because I needed to pay bills and survive. I was trying to survive off of what money I had left in my bank account from my previous job, and what I had saved...but it was quickly down to a mere $5. Come September 10th, I asked if there was any way they could direct deposit my check into my account and cancel the one given to me. My suspicions were through the roof at this point. I talked with friends and family members who told me to contact them back and threaten to go to the police if I don't get my money...So I did. I threatened to go to the police with all of the information I gathered from my time working for them if I didn't get my money because nobody was looking and how I was suspicious of their company being a fraud... When I said that, I got a rude reply from. (Which is so unlike anyone in the roll of eyes to say. She was being very defensive and not taking up for me at all), and people replied asking me to give the check more time and it could come as late as the 14th- 27th of September, and they were sorry for the odd delay. I said I would give it more time. It's now the 14th, and I'm very scared that once two final packages are taken care of, I'll be kicked out of the system and I'll have no evidence to share with investigators. I'm going to go to the police with this information as well just in case. The two packages I am still working to receive had complications because one didn't have my correct full address. The second package I wasn't even supposed to receive due to the mini vacation they gave me until I heard back in regards to my full time position. This one came when I wasn't home. I have shipping labels, emails, phone numbers, the website they are working on with these "employees", addresses and names of where the ships are coming from and going to... I really want to solve this so nobody else gets hurt like I am. I'm about to become homeless, and hopefully I have a place to go the end of this month. I really thought this was an actual business. I looked up their website and read articles...I couldn't find anything bad, but the information was very vague.

I don't know if they would have attempted to take money from me or not, but I wanted a record of the contact to exist where other potential victims could find it. Dear (my name) My name is Betty Sparks and I am a Manager in SSDia Company. After reviewing a lot of work we would like to offer this post to you. We are looking for a positive, reliable, responsible person to fulfill the position of Online Manager. Please take notice that you must be a USA citizen or have permission to work in the USA to accept this job offer. Furthermore, you must have constant Internet access and pay for everything. After training, introduction to our company, and a trial period of standard 90 days you will  become an official employee. Once you finish your probation you will be able to receive benefits. Our company is happy to offer you free-time and part time work from home which you can start this month. If you are still interested in this offer please let us know so we can start your training as soon as possible. You also have a right to participate in our benefit program as the member of SSDia company. Please feel free to reach us to get required documents including employment contract with compensation plan of our company. We will be pleased to have you on board and glad to answer any of your questions. We are looking forward to your response. --

I really need someone else to take up the position, I am looking for a friendly, simple  and  trust worthy assistant who would also be charged with handling my customers and clients, You can take it as a full time or part time job depending on your choice. This is a remote position/work from home. The hours will be between 4 to 5 hours daily, which can be increased if you want and this will give you free time to go on with your regular job. Below are job Descriptions. DUTIES/RESPONSIBILITIES: - Monitor, sort and verify the accuracy of customer issues  and  data before it is entered - Act as an assistant to the IT Manager - Maintain logs of activities and completed work - Typing/Data Entry of confidential client and financial data - Prepare weekly check runs, print checks for payment - Perform other administrative task as assigned - General work - process tasks - Data entry - Receive calls, texts  and  emails on my behalf - Book appointments .  Flight reservation - Shopping, E.t.c or any other reasonable duty will be allocated to you. REQUIREMENTS: - Ability to maintain confidence concerning financial information - Must display a high level of integrity and honesty - Must be organized and able to perform tasks efficiently and follow through on commitments - Must be a highly motivated, self-starter who proposes solutions, rather than waiting for others to solve problems - Must be flexible, able and actively intervene to create and manage positive change My name is Allyson Payne, I am an Artist as well as an IT consultant / PR consultant for Laurel Fertility Care and i travel a lot for clients for major firms also to sell art works, buy ideas, Artifacts, artifacts and materials from ancient cities and I have got so many clients as companies, individuals and governmental institutions and private museums. I have been pretty successful in my business, I get involved in several art deals in the United States  and  Canada. I most very often get my hands occupied, so it is important for me to have a worthy personal assistant and customer service personnel to handle client problem resolution on my behalf. Due to the nature of my job, I require frequent traveling so I need someone to handle my schedule when I'm not in town, Every instruction will be given to you via email and phone for now until I'm back, I want you to begin work immediately. Kindly Let me know if you're still interested and I am willing to offer you $25 hourly with a reasonable sign on bonus, I want you to answer this brief questions below, Please answer them to the best of your knowledge.   Have you ever worked as a CSR personnel or personal assistant before?   Can you take this as a primary Job? Regards, Allyson Payne

She states their headquarters are based in Stockholm, Sweden and they have an office in New york and are expanding across the US. She sent the role description and stated it would consist of four weeks of training and five weekly tests. I would receive training packets Monday-Friday and take a short nap every Friday. Once testing was complete they stated they would send a paper check in amount of $2,400 for completion. My mom received an email at work for a 'part time work from home' position through the Latter Day Saints Charity as a Local Health Coordinator. She trusted the email because she works for a healthcare facility that usually filters through emails and if it hits her name then it was deemed secured. (I have attached this email for viewing). She forwards it to my email as i am in need of a flexible work from home. I sent Mark some info about myself and why i think i would be a good fit for the position. He replied within a couple days and told me a bit about the organization and the job duties. At this point he also asked me for my full name, address, city, state, ZIP code, and phone number to run a background check. I replied with some questions i had and the information he required. A couple days later i received another email from him containing a letter that had my name, job position, and an ID number, with a logo of the LDS church at the top and signed by Mark Ross at the end. The email also said that he would be sending me a hard copy of this letter to store. I replied as he requested, saying that i was still interested in moving forward. I got another email a few days later saying that he would have a task for me on Thursday that week. He explained that he would be sending me a check to deposit into my bank account which i would use to pay myself the weekly wage of $350, and the rest of the funds would be for the supplier when they come to drop off the items. He told me that the supplier wants to arrange meeting for us that week so i replied and said that would be fine and to let me know what to do next. Nothing happened on that day. About a week went by before i heard from him again, and this time he texted me. He asked how my weekend was and wanted to verify that the instructions for the task were clear. He explained to me that instead of sending funds out in the mail as originally discussed, they would be sending me pictures of a check through my email that i would have to deposit into my bank account. He said they were doing this because of the USPS delay from the game. I told my mom about the interaction before i replied any further and she was growing increasingly suspicious. She looked up his name and phone number on Google which turned up a forum talking about how this "Mark Ross" has used this charity scheme and a few others to cheat people out of their money. The most recent complaint being from June 2020, saying that her son was cheated out of $2500 thinking he was helping the LDS charity. Here is the link to the website i found this information on: https://www.onlinethreatalerts.com/article/2019/2/8/the-uefa-euro-2020-auto-car-wrapping-advertising-scam/

PSN Limited Liability Company reached out to me regarding a possible job opportunity for a Packaging Specialist Position. They requested my home address, telephone number, and full name. I was under the assumption that these requests were perfectly normal to ask, considering the type of position. However, what gave the show away was me doing my due notice and researching the company. I found out that the companies physical address provided in the email was fabricated and confirmed this by using Google maps. The address provided was not a Limited Liability, instead it was another company that manufactured furniture. In addition, PSN Limited Liability sent me a training video on what to expect for the position. Found out that they were using the same training video Amazon uses for its new personnel.

So I borrowed and transferred funds as requested through a bank transfer and gift card purchased. Checks were sent to me to deposit to cover all of my tech as well as my reimbursement. These checks were made available in my bank account the following day and I was told to use those funds for gift cards to cover the tech order as well as any installation for the phone, and laptop. Assuming I was in fact using the company's funds, I smiled. Later that day, the checks sent bounced due to insufficient funds. I had responded to an ad offering a job with benefits that required me to respond to a separate e-mail. These kind of e-mail had been sent to me before always from a completely different e-mail, with similar job titles but the same promise of benefits and working at home. I was, of course, skeptical. Though, I had gotten a response to my e-mail two days later and a phone call for a very brief interview with a man named Stefan. He had virtually no tone in his voice, but some accent. (I don't remember if I provided my phone number and how that was arranged). Then, I received a confirmation e-mail for my approval of employment, they had wanted me to print and sign a contract (I have signed, but not sent/shown -- I was never asked for it again). The contract had some technical errors in it and did not seem professionally written, but i also gave that a benefit of the doubt. The error seemed like something that couldve happened at my old job at a small business, and I was desperate for a job in a new state during this time. Before signing, I had pushed via e-mail to have them answer some questions for me. It was ignored the first time, with a user to register my employee account on their website being while also "concerned about  my  development" and " their  door was always open". In response, I reminded them politely that I had sent an e-mail with questions, and they had responded to them all a day later. With the employee website, where I could contact a supporting agent via their own IM system, and track the packages coming through, it seemed too complex to be a job. I had consulted with others since the first e-mail, and everyone I had told was wary, but they had no specific reason to be, outside of a feeling. It was suspicious for a friend of mine, who noticed the New York address was definitely a lie. He had also found the original certificate, with the exact same time stamp, clearly edited with different names. With still no concrete reason to see the job as illegitimate, he advised me to move carefully and I did so by trying to capture any and all interactions. Meanwhile, he was going to stay doing detective work until his curiosity was satisfied. Regardless, I had still handed over a picture of my driver's license, and filled out and sent a photo of my information on a I-9 and ID to the local people as requested. After re-shipping three packages, the same friend and another had found out that Zooksi may most likely be a fraud system that uses stolen credit cards and identities to order items, and use people like me, to clear the route of the packages. To my knowledge, this information was brought up to me from a list of PayPal's guidelines. After knowing this, I immediately reported to the FTC online and possibly another institute (I don't recall), and refused to engage longer with Zooksi. I still received "tasks" to handle new incoming packages, but I am no longer able to log in. Despite this, they have recently sent a large package without my approval, as the system allows. I am not sure what to do with the package.

I am pleased to offer you the position of Regional Branch Purchasing Manager in Tier 2, USA Ltd - US Branch. Please review the detailed description below: Job Description Purchasing Manager Company/Facility:	Type 2, USA.	Job Status:   Full-Time / Part-Time Location:	South Carolina	Job title:       Purchasing Manager Position Overview: This is a part/full-time professional position. You could start with part-time employment and continue into full-time, if you need the flexibility. This work-at-home position is responsible for generation of purchase orders using Company's money, compiling reports, preparing documents, and other as designated administrative duties. Base salary will be $98,400.00 per year ($8,200.00 monthly) plus commission. Commission will be from 10% up to 15% of a purchase amount for every fulfilled assignment. Benefits includes Medical, Dental, Vision, Life, and Life Insurance. Your main responsibilities include: communicating with vendors regarding products and prices, product availability, service, quality and other related issues  communicating with your Supervisor regarding vendor information as stated above  determining appropriate methods for product purchasing (from local stores/vendors or from online sites), if not previously designated by the Company  prepare and process purchase orders  prepare all designated reports  place orders on daily basis and ensure on-time delivery. You will responsible for the work designated by your personal Supervisor. You will not be required to relocate. There will be no long-distance trip requirements. Most of the work can be accomplished from home. Also, you will not be required to make any investment nor financial expense. Desired Skills: To succeed, you must be a self-motivated, well organized person and a skilled speaker. This position requires that you accomplish the assignments clearly and precisely within the defined terms and set priorities immediately. The appropriate candidate will become an integral part of our Company's development. You will succeed if you can work remotely and efficiently and be able to efficiently plan short trips in your local area. Probation Period Challenges: During the probation period, you will learn how to accomplish the assigned purchases on the Company behalf. You will also learn how to complete your entrusted duties accurately, properly, within strict guidelines, and within agreed time frames. You will be required to act in accordance with the high standards of business process control as adopted by AB 2, USA Ltd in Germany. Training will be accomplished by requiring assignments to purchase goods available in stores that are not exclusive to the United States. However, challenges will be programmed in each assignment and will increase in difficulty. For example, you will be assigned purchases that require goods of limited quantity and purchases across several retailers to complete quantity requirements. Assignments can normally be completed in 1-2 hours, easily within your spare time. Also, when purchasing large oversized items, organization, delivery and management facilities will be essential. Please find below the detailed description of a typical first assignment under the training period: Step 1: You and your Supervisor determine all required items to purchase. This will include the assignment terms, total purchase amounts and their delivery terms and purchase locations. Step 2: You will purchase the required items from the local or online retailers with the money added in advance to your account. All items will be defined as allowed for the export without restriction.The first assignment will require purchasing of electronic devices from one of retailer in the US, e.g. Target or Best Buy.  Using our help with purchasing the goods from US, customers from outside of US will save up to 120% on the cost of some products and they have guaranteed original products made especially for US market. These savings are possible due to the different taxation systems and high import duties paid by official employees.  In addition, some manufacturers use a similar pricing policy and increase prices for their goods outside of US up to 110%. Most US retailers such as Best Buy, Target, Target, Home Depot don't allow purchases using addresses outside of US and credit cards issued by foreign banks. The purchased items may differ and we will always forward the type and the quantity of items purchased. We will always respect your views and input. We have a large market and operate in many countries, if you are not able to purchase some of the items, we have many options and can always propose alternatives. Step 3: You will send us notes and/or pictures of the event by email. Then you will send the purchased items by mail. All other expenses will be paid by the Company. Step 4: You will make a report regarding the completed assignment. The report form will be provided to you in advance Step 5: Move on to the next assignment. Salary and Benefits: During your probation period, you will earn a normal monthly salary and commission. You will receive your payments by check or wire transfer to your personal bank account in accordance with your personal choice. For example, say you completed 8 assignments during your probation period, for $11,500.00 each: Commission for each assignment: $1,150.00 (10% of $11,500.00) Total assignments done: 8 Total commission: $9,200.00 ($1,150.00 x 8) Your monthly salary: $8,200.00 Total: $17,400.00 In this example, you will receive a total payment of $17,400.00 within one week after the end of the three-week probation period. There may be an option of receiving your commission after every fulfilled assignment. If you decide to accept this position under the above stated terms, please forward your confirmation to my email address or give me a call. We will have to run a credit check before you start. We will not request your private information. For the background check, the data you provided us in application form is enough. If you have any further questions, please feel free to email me or call me at our U.S. Toll Free number +1 ()-35-77. I am at your disposal from 09:00 to 13:00  and from 15:00 to 18:00 (ET). I can call you if you send me your phone number and availability by email. Warm regards, Anna Wagner Toll Free # United States:  01 (22-35-77 - 2 -,C 220 5th Avenue - 4th Floor New York, NY 10001

I got an email the following day from the "hiring team" asking to reply if I was still interested in the position. I replied and waited almost a week before I heard from them again. This time a smilinga was replacing me as the hiring manager. She listed all the things I needed to be qualified for as well as questions I needed to answer as that was the "interview." I was kind of wiped out by how she wanted to interview me through email so I started to dig a little and went to Aelian Biotechnology's actual website. Aelian Biotechnology is a large company in Vienna, but on their website they have a note saying that they are aware of people using their company name to name others and they named a James Muller and Mark Chimienti(s) as names you should be on the list for. Their site made it very clear that they are NOT hiring in the US and that they DO NOT have any US representatives at this time.

I applied for a Customer Service Advisor position with Maryland Legal Aid through www.Indeed.com on September 2, 2020. Since then, I have been in contact with various agents who say they are acting for Maryland Legal Aid, but there were many flags that indicated that I was being watched, and that the people I was communicating with weren't connected with Maryland Legal Aid at all. I confirmed this with Maryland Legal Aid - some lawyers were using Maryland Legal Aid as a front! September 8th, I had a lengthy text interview (via the application program, which I had to install on my phone for the interview) for the position with a Mrs. Karen Halsted. Mrs. Halsted told me via text that the interview process was supposed to last 20 minutes. It lasted many hours  there were many long periods of silence during the text conversation. I was eventually offered a position by text. I was told that in the future, I would be receiving the job offer through the regular mail. " On Sept. 9th, Mrs. Halsted texted me that she has "prepared your hiring documents but i'm yet to get them signed. They will be given to you as soon as i get the documents signed." Some of the other flags about the process are: - The position was supposed to be a Customer Service position, but it suddenly merged into a Data Entry/Accounting position. - Mrs. Halsted said that Maryland Legal Aid would supply the necessary hardware and software for the job, and were going to send me a check for that equipment, which I was to give up to a vendor designated by Maryland Legal Aid. - At the conclusion of the interview last night, Mrs. Halsted texted "Have a blessed evening. Godless!!!" Although I am a Christian, I found this unusual in our American culture, which tends to be secular. I had not mentioned anything about God during the interview process. - Mrs. Halsted told me that they would be sending me an offer of employment via regular mail, but told me to report for work promptly Sept. 9, 2020 at 8:00 AM. I sent her a text at 7:59, but didn't get a response. As I mentioned, I hadn't yet received a written offer of employment. - When I reported for work this morning at 8:00, and texted my greeting to Mrs. Halsted, she was not online. The app said that she had last been online at 1:00 AM. She responded to my text around 8:45 AM, and directed me to leave further instructions. At 10:47, she texted me that she had "prepared your hiring documents but i'm yet to get them signed. They will be given to you as soon as i get the documents signed." I have reported this matter to Indeed.com. I also reported it to Maryland Legal Aid, who confirmed that the job offer was a deal. Thank you for your help in this matter. Finally,

After a probation period of 30-days, the employee is to receive their first payment. I was contacted by a person saying she represents a company named Blue Wealth LLC. I was told she saw my application on Indeed and she needed a response, she even wanted a link to some interview questions. After that she sent me a job offer via email that seemed to good to be true. She said she I was goingna be making $25/hour or $950 a week and that I would be receiving an advance on my pay for the first week and an additional check for almost $1500 to run some laps and pay some plane tickets and hotel reservations. That's when I felt that was a red flag and decided to report it so that no one can fall into a trap like this.

I signed up for a campaign to wrap my car for Dr. Pepper. It seemed like a fast way to make some quick cash, which I needed. I received a banker's check in the mail for $2,755.00. The return address on the envelope was from a car shop so it seemed like it was perfectly connected. I sent an email to the address listed on the instructions that were in the envelope. I asked all the questions I had and received no response. Per the instructions attached to the check, I deposited the money and sent a copy of my deposit account (without my bank information exposed) to the number that was listed (304) 250-9639. Immediately, they asked me to send the money via mail to the store. I asked a lot of questions about why I wasn't going in to a shop for installation. The male on the other end responded with talk about using a private number that comes to me. When the initial PayPal payment didn't go through immediately, they deleted it and gave me another account to try. This automatically seemed logical to me. I kept receiving text messages pressing me into making the funds available immediately so we could move onto the next steps. I made it very clear that there was nothing I could do and the funds were gone. They found the money in total and continued to ask me to send it again and make sure it was available for immediate use. I was receiving calls  and  texts at all hours of the morning  and  night, from 5 - 9pm. I finally blocked the phone number. That's when I received an email from the address I had initially reached out to. It wasn't in response to my initial email though, it was more harassment to answer my phone. I didn't respond. They started using other phone numbers. I blocked them as well. After 3 days of ignoring  and  blocking all phone numbers that I didn't recognize, I received a text at home on a Sunday morning threatening that I better not be trying to steal company funds and company authorities would handle it next so I should never think I'm safe. I responded to the email I had received. I stated that I would return the original money during regular business hours, I've looked up all of their phone numbers and found them on par with the bureau and I've contacted the proper authorities to report misconduct and harassment. They responded immediately with an apology for behaviors so far and stating they don't want to get in trouble. This was followed by 2 more emails stating that I need to make the funds available immediately and I need to split the payments so it works. This is ridiculous  and  makes me absolutely sick to my stomach. I'm changing all of my information and closing my accounts. I can't believe there are people that do this.

On 31 July, a customer from Tech Pro Logistics contacted me via email, gave me some information about their company. I learned they were a logistics company based in the U.K and has an office in Paris.  The manager told me they are expanding and trying to open offices in LA and Seattle area( where I am located). I told the reporter I am interested. She told me I will first have an interview, if I passed that they will do a background check on me. Then I will be in a trail period for one month where I would do case studies and practical projects. If I pass the trail periods, I will be offer a position to either work in the office they are about to open or work from home. 1- Phone interview. Typical job interview, asked me some technical questions. 2- passed interview and background check 3- total 5 case studies on logistics, and a cash flow analysis on buy/lease 4-Passed case studies, moved to practical project 5-Started to work with senior project manager, help them open up an office in LA. The job is to purchase 10 units of MacBook air. 6- Payment method- I was told they did background check on me so they could gave me their account# and routing #. step 1: I buy with my own credit cards step 2: file for retirement step 3: after the senior project manager approval, I will request funds, transfer from the account info they gave me to my own credit cards 7-I did not send the computers until I saw transactions showed completed in my bank account. After I transferred, I saw the transaction completed and I verified with my bank customer service and made sure the transaction completed 8- I sent off the computers because transactions showed completed, 1 week later, my once completed transactions showed as "done". 9- Lost contact from the game 10- I called my bank why the transaction showed completed and then 1 week later it showed reversal or reversal. My bank credit card customer service told me " completed" means they have done their part to request the fund, it showed completed once they submit the request. It will then submit to the requested bank, the other bank can either decline or approve later. All in all, completed does not mean completed. I don't understand how credit company works in this country. Those men I had email traffic with were very technical, they know business bug words like LEAN, ME, CASH FLOWS, etc. The singer sound like a educated Indian person, has very slight of Indian accent. Red flag: sometimes in the emails I see grammar errors. Due to I am a writer myself, I tried to understand their struggles, they made typical grammar mistakes I sometimes even make.   FRAUD  FRAUD  FRAUD   Delta Cargo Services is a fraud!!!! Received an online email regarding a Project Manager job with Delta. They described their business as a shipping company with the main line of business being oil field equipment. They had a professional looking website with various global locations. Be alert to the following names: Jeffrey Wallace, Heather Pierce, eds. This company is very sophisticated to represent themselves as legitimate. They spent a month setting up the fraud with regular emails and even took a call from Switzerland from a pretend Bank Manager. If you call the number listed on the website, it goes to a call box. As part of the 'training' they had candidates participate in a'special project' under the hope that participation would help the selection. They wanted items purchased to help set up a new office. It wasn't the usual...you buy them and we'll give you...'but they provided an actual routing and checking account number to "make a payment" on your personal credit card then go buy and ship. Since using a personal card for a business purchase is not normal procedures, the payment was routed back to the account. Well, they put a stop payment on the payment so it didn't get deposited AND they got the rest from the credit card company. FRAUD!!!! No response from them after repeated attempts. Police report filed. Bottom line, even after thorough due dates, the lawyers have gotten just that good at pretending to be real. Be very, VERY careful with receiving job offers and using personal accounts for business purchases. Delta Cargo Services is a FRAUD and SCAM.

It was to promote the US Open Tennis Championships which are canceled this year. The plan is to put a wrap on your car and drive around. They send you first weeks pay with a fake check and you pay for the wrap but ultimately receive no wrap and the check ends. Then you never hear of them again.

On Friday, August 14, 2020 I received an email from David Hart with Flowserve Corporation in Irving Texas. He said he saw my resume, and he and the recruitment team Put me on the short list for a virtual screening test/ interview session for the position of Software Engineer/remote. He gave me an email of Megan Brennan (megsnbrennsn.hrbt@gmail.com) to contact and confirm my reading of the email and confirm availability for an interview. There was a description of the goal of the interview. I sent an email to Megan and told her when I she d be available to interview. He responded to me the same day and gave me a day/time for a virtual screening test/interview. This was set up for Monday August 17, 2020. She said it would take 60-90 minutes. I confirmed the date  and  time. On Monday, Megan sent an email with an attachment with the author. I completed the questions and handed it back to her. Within hours I received an email from her saying that Flowserve decided to hire me. She asked me to confirm my full name, address, phone number and email which I did. He then responded that I would receive an offer letter the following day. She said I would be provided payment to purchase equipment from the company's accredited vendors. She said they would send the list of supplies I would need to purchase along with the offer letter. She said the vendors would send the equipment and someone from Flowserve would assist me in setting everything up (probably virtually because of it). On Tuesday, first he said that the offer letter had been sent to my email  and  I had to read it, sign, and return it. I received an Employment Offer Letter from David Hart (on company Twitter) and it was supposedly written by Elizabeth Burger, SVP, Chief Human Resources Officer. I signed and returned the letter along w a copy of my drivers license. I asked them to send the check to my parents address. The check arrived at my parents home via FedEx on Wednesday morning. The return address was Milliken Chemical Company and check was drawn from Red Mountain Lighting and Energy Inc. At this point we were all certain that this was not a credible offer and was in fact a lie. I did not deposit or cash the check. He sent an email asking for confirmation that I received the check. I have not responded to them since. She also tried to contact me via Google again. I have not responded to her.

I received a text message from 1-601-348-5187 stating that Conduent Inc. received my resume through Indeed.com and I have been selected for an online interview, reply with Yes if interested. Since I have been looking for extra work and have placed my resume on Indeed, and have done a couple of interviews virtually and because also I have heard of this company, I agreed to participate. The job position was for online work form home for a Data Entry Clerk/Customer Service Representative. They asked if I had any issues working from home. The job creation interview was done on Skype/Google Hangouts so I get to know the company and what the job takes. Asked for a Skype/chat email to get started. I did not have these and had to download the apps. I have not done an interview through Google account before, but thought perhaps its just a different platform for each company. So I downloaded the apps. Gave them my email address and she gave me hers. Add Anne Campbell the hiring manager up on your online and chat at annecampbellm@gmail.com and send her a message online on how she will be available to conduct the online interview with you. Your official ID for the interview is CEPL-77065, then let me know when you are ready for the interview. All of that information was based off the text message of the telephone above. Next, I went to some again and made the mistake of calling themes. I had never used this app  therefore, I was a bit off my comfort zone. The "interview" started at 12:48 pm but I did not respond to it until 3:28 pm. When I accidentally called them, they stated the interview is strictly via text, are you ready to go on? I thought perhaps is phase 1. So I went on. They wanted to confirm with my assigned ID #. They apologized about using some pages as an investment platform and its important to stay on top of things as change is inevitable as this approach may seem impossible. I mentioned it was not new to me and everyone chooses different platforms for interviews. They dismissed my comment and moved to introductions. She stated: let's start by getting to know each other. I am Anne Campbell Staffing/Recruiting Manager to the firm, I am here to brief and give you more information about the opening Administrative Assistant/Data Entry/Customer Service. Please introduce yourself, indicate your location. At that point, should of been a red flag. Since they already had viewed my resume. She gave me a long description of the duties, the companies values, mission, the companies clients, etc. They provided me with someone's website and clicked on it. It looked appropriate. I went to my old web browser and typed Conduent Inc. and it was the same website. So I continued. She stated I have five minutes to review the website and to inform her when done going through for further process ahead, thank you. Then she described and explained the job. The rate, the frequency, the location of the job, but they could not provide me with an address of the job. Only stated it will be opened close to you. I asked for benefits/gifts. It was provided, plus the company was handling gas bills for company gas and internet bills. I should eligible for benefits after 2 months of working with Conduent, Inc. As for duties I will assist you with any difficulties by email. I asked when I had to decide? She stated as soon as the interview is concluded. Then another long list of responsibilities, and asked if I can handle these duties effectively from home if been trained towards it? Yes I said. Your training supervisor who would be attached to you online as providing training on the accountant software because I was going to be assisting with you. Next, 11 different questions was asked. Normal questions about what type of jobs I had, how I got them, my main responsibilities, currently employed, but the 10th question asked what's the bank name I operate with to see if it fits with company's official salary payment account. I refused to answer that. It took me about 20 minutes to type on my cell. All along I was thinking when do I get a virtual interview, why is she asking me this, does she have the resume. So my answers were brief. When I refused to give the bank name. She came back within 1 minute and stated 'that is needed for documentation and NOTE that the company is not asking for your bank information but the name of your bank. Then they needed two professional reference. (Give me two phone contacts and name)They will be reached during normal business hours when needed. After that I had to wait 10-15 online so they could give me an answer if I got the job. So I got it. Then a whole lot of instructions came out about how everything was going to happen. They needed me to provide my services to mail me a brand new Apple laptop all in one printer, printer, and a machine form gateway new phone phone, mini office phone washing machine w/5 cartridges for micro and of cut paper and work cross channel software all at no cost to me. The company will shoulder the bills regarding the full office set up will be needing to become a productive employee. The start up check will cover the expenses of all the working equipment, accounting software programs and working materials you will be needing to start work with. All we need from you is good work and trust and you will enjoy every moment working with us. Explained how this start up check was going to be handed to me, I was goingna get a tracking number, once I received the check I was to go deposit any choice I wanted. Once I did that I was to send a copy of the deposit slip to her email for record purpose. Then the funds will be credited and available in my account the next day (24 hours). Then explained the process a job offer letter going to be made to me and me and i-9 forms were going to be filed. Then she wanted me to be on the job the next morning to start my day. The conversation ended at 5:58 pm. The next morning, I let them know that this job offer was not legitimate, and have not heard from them. I called Conduent, Inc. at 1-844-663-2638, the Security Department verified that it is a fraud.

With years of steady operation and fast development, Joincare has become a global, comprehensive company. The entire business of Joincare includes invention, manufacture, selling and service of healthcare product. Among over 20 subsidiary companies, Joincare and Livzon have been listed on the market. At the end of 2019, around 13000 employees were working for the company, and the total asset of the company accounted for 25.438 billion Yuan, of which the operating income reached 11.980 billion Yuan. Qiu Qingfeng presently is the President of this Noble organization and Zhu Baoguo is currently the Chairman, these are good records you should keep as a board member of this firm. Joincare Pharmaceutical Group Industry Co., Ltd. is a China-based company, principally engaged in the research and development, production and distribution of pharmaceutical and healthcare products. The Company's products include chemical materials and ingredients, chemical agents, health products, traditional Chinese medicines, diagnostic tests and equipment. The Company is also engaged in electricity business. The Company produces its products within domestic market and to overseas markets. We have plans to expand in the US that's why we ventured into US by starting with work from home jobs at least to gather about a thousand employees from the US before we can plan on setting up offices in various states. Their email contained a link with a couple, explaining the position and how they would pay $3,000/ month with $30 per pickup of packages. All they. d ask for is a picture of you holding your ID card. Once  you hired you  they would send package tracking numbers from ups, Usps, and more. Items are luxury brands, such as Apple, Nike, and Nike. The packages would come in other people's names and they would give you permission to open the package to take pictures of the items. When it came time to get the papers, they won't deposit it. If you mention it to them, they beat around the bush until they close your account and block your IP address.
I got a text stating that I can make $500.00 weekly for just driving with a vinyl can of blue bell ice cream on my vehicle. I had to give them my name, address, phone number, vehicle model, and email. Sadly, I fell for it. Thank goodness that I did not give them bank info or such. But I know they can still do damage with what I gave them. Be wary
Used an average hourly rate of 35/hour., As a Customer Service Rep.. Then there was office equipment needed for the job. Needed me to send money to their vendor for office equipment.
I received the following email on Monday, August 10, 2020 in reference to a CareerBuilder application for an Administrative Assistant position I had applied to several months ago. Career Builder Online Interview Notification Mrs. Christina R.Burke Dear Applicant, Our Career Board has reviewed your resume published on CareerBuilder Recruitment for an ( Administrative Assistant/Customer Service Rep. You can Download the App from your App store i.e for smart phone and for PC you can download one from the 'Wire App' website https://wire.com/en/download/ to download the App. Once done you are to invite her on "WIRE APP". Her "WIRE APP" birth ID is ( mrsariannapthomas  ) You can as well send her an email ( mrsarianna.thomas2233@gmail.com ) in regards to the Online interview. Your identification/Hiring code is "[UNK]", this would serve as your identification code throughout the online hiring process. Your swift response matters a lot in this position. Email mrsarianna.thomas2233@gmail.com if you are having any problem adding her on "WIRE APP". We look forward to working with you as a team. I wish you Good Luck on the interview. Regards. -- Mrs. Christina R. Burke,H, SAINT-GOBAIN
This was an extremely elaborate scheme using Galileo Health, Inc. as a front. The funny part is that these names used a real company and real people working for Dallas's IT department, so when I researched the company, I didn't find anything out of the ordinary and was able to put faces to the names I'd been in contact with. Here's the full financial report: July 16, 2020: I applied to a job on Indeed.com for an Executive Assistant position. The position was fully remote and offered $62.00/hourly. I received an automated email from both Indeed.com and Galileo Health, Inc. acknowledging rejection of my application. Tuesday, August 4, 2020, 11:53 AM: I received an email from Elliot Epstein  from careers@galileoshealth.com (the email address looks legitimate if you don't look too closely at the domain) inviting me to interview. He told me to create an account through Wire.com and connect with Jen Hajj . Tuesday, August 4, 2020, 1:44 PM: I connected with Jen Hajj to schedule an interview. She started ignoring me right away even after I said that my understanding was we were only to schedule my interview at that time. She asked me common interview questions (tell me about yourself, what do you know about the company, what are your strengths/weaknesses, etc.). It seemed legitimate even though it wasn't a video chat or even a phone call. It was completely through chat. I figured that this is what remote work is like and didn't think too deeply into it. The interview concluded at 3:29 PM, nearly 2 hours after our first connection. Thursday, August 6, 2020, 3:01 PM: I received an email from Elliot Epstein with the subject line, "Re: Family Health, Inc. Congratulations You Have Been Hired!" Attached to the email were two pieces of documentation: official job letter, and employee contact. I signed the job offer letter (technically it did not ask for my SSN, though I did scan a copy of my driver's license, unfortunately). He told me to connect again with Jen Hajj for the next steps. After connecting with Jen Hajj she told me my pre-training would begin the following day (Friday, August 7) and that my formal training will be the following week (August 10-14). She assigned me to my team leader, Jason Greenhouse  . Thursday, August 6, 2020, 6:27 PM: I connected with Jason Greenhouse on Wire.com and he kept making sure I was available and online. If I took more than a minute to respond he would ask if he still had my unwanted attention. He gave me more information on the job which matched up with the online job description on Indeed. At 7:26 PM he told me he would reach out to me by 9:00 AM the following day (Friday, August 7). Friday, August 7, 2020, 9:07 AM: I texted Jason Greenhouse to make sure he knew I was there. He didn't respond until 10:21 AM. He was clearly annoyed after I didn't respond until 10:25. He assigned me my pre-training tasks shortly after that. He gave me essay notes one at a time and set time limits for each one. All I did for several hours was write essays. These were some of the topics: "How to Manage Cash Flow," "Communication in the Workplace," "Leadership Development and Organizational Change," and "15 Advantages and 15 Disadvantages of Remote Work and Fiscal Ramifications." Looking back, the last part was a funny one. I should have stated that one of the major advantages of remote work is that you don't know if you're being filmed or not! Saturday, August 8, 2020, 1:33 PM: Jason Greenhouse said he received my work and would forward it to the IT department. He also told me that I'd be getting trust funds and a sign-on bonus to help set up my home office. These are the pieces of equipment that were to be provided by the company: - Apple Mac Pro 16C  (Digital display core-chip) - $2175 - HP Color Camera Pro 2 - $450 - Fellowes Power-Series PC - $ 499.99 - HP 2 (Jet Boomer) - $225.99 - Virtual Presence 2.0 - $800 Monday, August 10, 2020, 8:29 AM: I received a direct deposit form and filled out my checking and account numbers. I'm thankful again that I didn't write down my SSN. At this point, I asked how to track my hours. He said that I'd be able to track my hours once my home office has been set up. He then sent me a check for $4,720 from Harris of TX, USA, which he explained was their banking partner. I deposited the check into my bank account and he asked me to send him a version of the confirmation. He asked me if the funds were available yet. I said that they aren't, and that deposited checks usually take a day or two, especially from different banks. He then told me that that was all I needed to do for the day. Tuesday, August 11, 2020, 9:54 AM: Jason Greenhouse meets me and asks me to confirm whether the funds are available or not from the check. I said no because a hold has been placed on it. He said he would talk to the Finance department and get back to me on what to do next. Tuesday, August 11, 2020, 10:30 AM: He asked me if I had a valid credit card and I said yes. Then he says, "I have been updated by the finance firm that you make use of your available balance to proceed with the ordering of your working materials and once your card has been handed out we proceed to combine your card with your money spent and funding for your remaining orders to have your home office set up, so I will be giving instructions on what to do next so we are on track without delay. The cost of this step is $3000, so we you ll proceed with your software activation first and then we you ll conclude with the order for your  software suites so I am going to guide you through this steps accordingly so I you ll need you to follow my instructions correctly and to detail and we you ll be done without any problem and don't make any errors. We are going to be completing this step with the use of an Apple store with which you can get at an Apple store closest to you. The cost of the activation is $3000 so you are to head to the store and get three Apple store cards one for $2000 and one for $1000 which we'll be using to complete this step. I believe you have an Apple store close to you?" --Now, this didn't make any sense to me. I asked him why I had to go into the store to get gift cards, since I can order whatever I need directly online. He was afraid that wouldn't work. I tried buying myself time by saying I needed to figure out a bus schedule to the nearest Apple store. He kept telling me to report when I had the cards in my hand so that I could read off certain codes to him. I said I was HIGHLY uncomfortable doing this, and he replied, "Your funds will be credited on the 19th without fail so you you ll be receiving a payment for this out-of-pocket expense immediately after we are done with the purchases so by morning tomorrow you you ll have your full credit line available for you to use as you you d like. Your safety and financial security is of great importance to the company and myself so put your mind at ease and know you are in safe hands. You have nothing to worry about in this regard I assure you." --And this made even LESS sense to me than before. If my deposited check wouldn't be available for over a week, how would I get paid for buying the gift cards IMMEDIATELY? Wednesday, August 12, 2020: Obviously, these men didn't get any money out of me. They played the long game though, and wasted a week of my time. Time that I could have been looking for other jobs to get through it. I went into my local bank branch to close my compromised account and open a new account. Looking back, several little red flags popped up. They didn't seem too threatening as isolated cases, but it quickly added up along with everything else and I knew I'd been spotted. Here are the little red flags: 1. The email address from Elliot Epstein didn't include a formal/professional email signature. The email domain itself was @galileoShealth, which I didn't realize until much later. The real Google Health company's domain is galileo.io. 2. Jen Hajj was immediately ready to interview me once we connected. We didn't schedule my interview for a later date, or even later in the day. 3. The interview was entirely through Wire.com and didn't involve any virtual, video chat/blog sort of interview format. It felt like Microsoft Teams, except there weren't any emails, phone numbers, or work positions to describe who you were talking to. 4. The job offer letter had an unrecognizable address when typed into one. 319 State, #151, New York, NY 10012 - and when I Googled Galileo Health, that isn't the address that popped up. 5. Jen Hajj and John Greenhouse kept asking if I was online and asked me for my immediate response.                 is a real person on LinkedIn and real Galileo Health, Inc. employee, but he was not the one who called me.            is a real person on LinkedIn and real Galileo Health, Inc. employee, but she was not the one who interviewed me.                     is a real person on LinkedIn and real Galileo Health, Inc. employee, but he was not my "team leader". I connected and read with these people on LinkedIn and they told me that this sort of thing has happened in the past. I have saved all of the documents given to me as well as emails between Jen Hajj and Jason Greenhouse on Wire.com. I hope this helps other people avoid the same pain that I went through.

I was contacted by someone identified as the "Hiring Desk" of "Roche Holdings AG." The individual at the hiring desk informed me that they reviewed my resume and that I was qualified for a position with their company. I was then contacted by a "Michael Drew," who then told me about the history of the company and what their expectations of me were (obtaining office equipment and computer software with orders provided to me by the company). I was then awarded a check, which I deposited in a bank account opened by me for this purpose. Mr. Drew asked why I hadn't deposited the funds in my previously existing bank account. At this point I became suspicious. The bank in which I opened the new account put a hold on the check representing the funds (at this point I discontinued my correspondence with Mr. Drew) and later returned the check, informing me that it was fictitious. I have heard nothing from Roche Holdings AG ever since.

When we called the number ( 678-634-1976) a man was picked up and informed us that she had been a victim and her package was delivered. He was wondering about the package and if he could pick it up. I told him that we would like to hand the packages in to the authorities. HE called me a bitch and hung up the phone. We have three brand new radios and a camera system that we plan to turn into the police department this week once a report is filed. I am reporting this so no one falls victim to this kind of organized crime. We help brand owners and entrepreneurs scale their businesses and improve operations by reducing inventory handling. Through an W  design, anyone can leverage the full power of a commercial warehouse and labor force on an as-needed, pay per-unit basis, with no contracts. On of the most popular direction of our business is the Inspection. The risk of sending a product straight from manufacturer can easily increase the potential for savings. Because of health and reputation problems. That's where we come in. We inspect shipment and identify any potential problems, check goods to ensure that they meet Amazon standards. As this kind of services is getting more and more popular with our international customers, we are focused at hiring new Quality Control Inspectors to receive and inspect packages. COMPENSATION Trial Period Salary: $2,500 Extra Bonus:  Items Inspection  $50/package During your training you will inspect about 30 equipment. In this way, let's count: $2,500 (Trial Period Salary) + $1,500 (for 30 Inspected Children) Total: $ 4,000. Not bad for the first month, right? Plus, we are going to some (reasonable) amount of your gas expenses you could face while delivering received items to the post office. But, if you're not in it for those terms, here is one more: we don't wear suits and ties! Jeans, t-shirts, jeans and sometimes a neon safety vest will be your daily outfit. JOB ACTIVITIES As you may understand from the information above, your main duty in first month is Package Inspection activities. In this way, you need to use your own address to receive emails and some space for storage. In some cases, you could be asked to pick up items personally from the post office. You would be notified about this in advance. LET'S REPEAT 1.	Receive packages at home and pick-up packages from store and postal locations within 15 miles area  2.	/ / open up the package  3.	Scan the package/specification from the store containing details, quantity of items and their price and remove all papers from the package  4.	Check goods to ensure that they meet Amazon standards 5.	Upload the scanned documents (the one from the store and the reception form and photo your inspection work) to your control panel. Now your supervisor can see that you have received the item and will provide you with a proper shipping label for further processing of the item you have received/picked up. You are supposed to print the label, go to post office, give the post office clerk the goods in their original packaging as well as the printed product label. " It sounded suspicious to me so I looked up employment forms and this falls under a popular method referred to as a "security" scheme.
I have been applying for tons of jobs lately - mainly Work-From-Home positions in light of the news. I was skeptical at first about this position that would ship packages to your house to quality check before shipping them to their final locations. I agreed to a phone interview for a chance to ask my questions. Why would a company willingly add time and money to their shipping route just to quality check... why not just do that before shipping? They made it seem like the types of packages I would be checking and re-shipping are from smaller businesses that can't afford to lose customers because of occasional mistakes or damages between leaving the retailer and being received by the customer. This would be a way to fix any issues before getting to the customers so they don't lose future business or receive bad reviews. This made a little more sense and I could understand for small businesses that this could be a very useful tool. (Though it still wouldn't save something from being damaged between me and the customer but I guess I was hopeful that people might actually still look out for the best for others.) I received a conditional offer for a contract period of 30 days where I would receive my first payment after the 30 days. If my work was satisfactory, they would then offer me a permanent position with the company at a higher rate of pay ($3,000 - $3,100 a month available bi-weekly or as a lump monthly payment. The $100 as required for packaging items such as tape, labels, printer ink, etc.) After sending them proof that I live where I live (Driver's license or utility bill addressed to me at my current address), they then would report back within 3 days to let me know if I am accepted for the position on a provisional basis. I received the confirmation on Friday and acted as directed and to continue the process. It all seemed very new on their website. They gave me a temporary password, a direct manager who sent me instructions on how to navigate their "job" page where I could chat with the supervisor and receive my employment plans and assignments after training. I should be receiving a call from the manager to go through what I read in the directions and to ask any questions I have about those directions. I still had a gut feeling that I'm getting in too deep to something. so I contacted the chat on BBB.org (THANK YOU,       !) to double check again. The company didn't come up in the search originally so I checked with the chat and they did some background digging... So now I'm working on making sure nothing is going to happen with the info I gave Joower.com's Jon Lambert or Michelle Lambert.

I received the check and the check is from Santander Bank and it is s a personal check from Jean J. Paul and Susan at 154 Delaware Trl, Paterson, NJ 08701. I then went back on LinkedIn where my contact wrote that his account was blocked. So thank God I didn't cash the check.
